child: Thief hoping to gain bigger booty, loses smaller.

Thieves directed to a hornet’s nest as supposed money
hiding place.

Two cheats exchange articles as genuine and both find
themselves cheated.

content: Stolen object magically returns to owner.

Irish myth: *Cross. See
all references to †D1602 and its subdivisions.

Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 130 No. 1525G*; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Benga):
Nassau 160 No. 20; West Indies: Flowers 508.
child: Confederate allows self to be sold as slave.

Rent a room at an inn and empty the mattresses of feathers, take fire wood,
etc. Throw goods out of the window where confederate picks it up. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Wife tells him secret of buried money. Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II
1014.

content: King‘s daughter put into brothel to catch thief.
Quartered thief‘s body sewed together to escape detection.

Trickster kisses pile of money, taking some in his mouth with every kiss.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Repentant thief pretends to have found stolen cow.

Upbraids owner for not
guarding her better. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 119 No. C; Mensa Philosophica No.
52.
child: Thief pretends to have recovered stolen horse.

Returns it to owner
after using it all he desires. Nouvelles Récréations No. 24.

content: Thief swallows stolen goods to escape detection.
child: Flower thief eats flowers to escape detection.

content:
Detection of theft of bull escaped by putting boots on
bull.
Thieves stretch chain across road and evade pursuers.
Trickster hides in food and eats it.

India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 57,
Coster-Wijsman 35 No. 16; Africa (Thonga): Junod 209.
child: Trickster throws fish off the wagon.

The fox plays dead; a
man throws him on the wagon of fish. The fox throws the fish off and carries
them away. *Type 1; BP II 116; Dh IV 225, 304; Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO
VI) 46ff. -- Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr II 3, III 3; Louisiana Creole:
Fortier MAFLS II 115; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 438;
Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 16 No. 8; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 17
No. 4, 306 No. 52, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 39, Stewart JAFL XXXII
395, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 276;
Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 10.

content:
A rascal steals a priest’s watch. He tells the priest that
he has stolen a watch and offers it to him as a payment for a past favor. The
priest refuses to accept stolen goods. Commands the thief to return the watch
to the owner. “But the owner has refused to accept it.” “Then you may keep it.”
Danish: Kristensen Kirketjeneste 126.

child:
Jackal ordered to take meat to lion‘s family takes it to
his own.
Man calling self “her husband” abducts child.
Tricksters eat up food given them for bear.
Man eats up food given him by tiger as bait for deer.

Monk entrusted with care of getting husband for girl, takes
dowry himself.

Uncle entrusted with niece’s patrimony slanders her so
marriage will be broken off and he will not have to part with her money.

Covetous husband desiring wife‘s jewels tells her he has
vowed to offer them to deity.

content:
Thieves steal chickens and have mock funeral to cover
theft.
Trickster pretends to teach dance: flees with valuables.

Trickster brings rabbit under his coat. When the king‘s watchdog gives chase
the trickster enters and robs. DeVries FFC LXXIII 208f.

In one cask is oil; in the others the robbers are hidden.
The girl kills them. *Type 954; *Penzer I 133 n. 1; *Fb “kiste” II 134; Chauvin V 83 n.
3; *Basset 1001 Contes II 302; *Wesselski Archiv Orientální II 432; Missouri
French: Carrière; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 391.
child: Thief hidden in cage that is carried into house.

Entry by master thief into closely guarded city in
wood-gatherer‘s basket.

content:
French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 23; Missouri French: Carrière;
India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Thief dressed half white, half black.

In the shroud of the supposed dead man is hidden another
robber. *Type 966*; India: Thompson-Balys.
Sham dead man brought in sack by confederate.

Is killed by his intended victim. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Thief disguises voice and is allowed access to goods
(children).

Type 123, BP I 37ff.; Africa
(Kaffir): Theal 118, (Zulu): Callaway 144, (Basuto): Jacottet 62ff.; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 236ff. Nos. 40, 42, 43; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS
XVII 116 No. 91.
Thief becomes monk in order to rob monastery.
Robber disguised as bear is killed.

Man allows himself to be carried off by monkeys, who
mistake him for cow: steals their magic cups.
Magician transforms self into crocodile to steal.
Steal hangings in palace. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Theft by disguise as son of owner.
Thief in disguise as long lost son-in-law.
Thief pretends to be girl’s bridegroom and calls for her.
Theft by disguise as owner‘s grandmother.
Thieves disguised as fine gentlemen steal provost’s purse.

Are admitted to court
without question. Nouvelles Récréations No. 80.
Theft by disguising as palace official.
Theft by disguise as woman servant.
Theft by disguise as merchant (or peddler).
Thief in the clothes of robbed bride kills bridegroom.

content: Thief copies key by making wax impression.

Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 312 No. 68; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child: Thief enters by burning off locks.

Entrance into wine cellar by removing lock during absence
of mother.
Theft from giant by fishing through chimney.

content: Thief enters treasury through secret passage.
child: Underground passage gives entrance to closed chamber.

Italian: Basile Pentamerone I No. 2; Jewish: Neuman;
India: *Thompson-Balys.

Thief enters treasury through passage made by him as
architect of the building.

Thief bores hole in house wall, then introduces blackened
pot as a feeler.

Thieves enter palace through hole in wall and abduct new
bride.

content:
Trickster feigns being pursued by drunken husband to obtain
entrance.
Marked culprit marks everyone else and escapes detection.
child:
Many persons admit theft so that it is impossible to find
real thief.

content: Magic statue betrays a thief by indirection.

He has threatened to smash the head of the magic statue if
it betrays him. The statue says, “Whoever would tell the truth now is likely to
have his head smashed.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 8.

child:
Thief feeds stolen money in flour to animal, then asks for
ass.

The trickster has a cow that leads the parson’s cows to
him. He thus tests the parson‘s text, “He who gives in God’s name shall have it
back a hundred-fold.” *Type 1735; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 324; *Krappe Bulletin
Hispanique XXXIX 25; *Wesselski Mönchslatein 167 No. 129.

Brothers are given the choice of a cow or a calf. One chooses the cow
and thinks that he has the best of the bargain. The cow longs for the calf and
returns to it. Indo-Chinese: Scott Indo-Chinese 296.

A
cow allows itself to be sold; then returns to its master. Hindu: Keith 90.
Animal shams death and is sold.
Later made to disgorge rice. India: Thompson-Balys.

Speaking goat swallows gold coins in temple and voids for
master.

content:
Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges; Africa (Luba): DeClerq Zs. f.
Kolonialsprachen IV 221; Philippine (Tinguian) Cole 195.
Theft by presenting false order to guardian.

*Wesselski Mönchslatein
126 No. 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 274; West
Indies: Flowers 506-8.
child:
Unique weapon got by misrepresenting to guardian use to
which it is to be put.

The numskull has been told to keep the sausage “for the long winter”. When the
trickster hears this, he claims to be Long Winter and receives the sausage.
*Type 1541; *Fb “tosse” III 832a, “pølse” II 907b; BP I 521, 526;
Christensen DF L 46; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 194 n. 3; Icelandic: Sveinsson FFC
LXXXIII No. 1541.
Ring to put on corpse’s finger.

A thief holds a corpse up to a lord‘s window. The lord shoots
the corpse and leaves to bury it. The thief goes to the lady and gets a sheet
to bury the corpse in and a ring to put on his finger. *Type 1525A; BP III 379;
Missouri French: Carrière; Jewish: Neuman.

A thief poses as a messenger from a husband
to his wife asking that a certain silver cup be sent for repairs. *Wesselski
Mönchslatein 126 No. 109; Scala Celi 101a No. 543; Mensa Philosophica No. 56;
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Stealing the platter for the intended gift.

Thief asks for silver platter saying that it is needed for
an intended gift of confections. Servant carrying platter is told to wait until
it is filled. Thief disappears with it. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Theft by posing as master of the house and learning where
goods are hidden.

Wife deceived in the dark. *Gering Islenzk Æventyri (Halle, 1883)
II 210ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Hare in lion’s skin gets meat from lioness.

Fox drinks the milk of a tiger’s mate by giving her a
misleading message.
S. A. Indian (Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 180.
Deposit money secured by false order to banker‘s wife.

When banker refuses to redeliver deposit the owner
presents false tokens to wife. Jewish: Bin Gorion Born Judas II 245.
Theft by forgery: signature forged to obtain money.

Clerk mistranslates order given by master to maid, so that
pie goes to clerks.

Thief steals lawyer’s scarlet robe. Later he returns and tells lawyer‘s wife
that her husband had sent him for the hood for the robe. He obtains the hood
and escapes. Spanish: Childers.

(Cf. †K437.5, †K1354.1.) Thief sent to man’s house for water, demands money. Man‘s wife refuses and
thief shouts to the husband who replies, “Give him what he wants.” India:
*Thompson-Balys.

Hero reports to king that his ancestors (in heaven) want
him rewarded with gold.

content:
Thief condemned when witnesses of theft are able to find
the stolen goods.

Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 48; West Indies: Flowers
509.
child:
Horse catches arm of thief and holds on until help comes.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Apparently dead woman revives when thief tries to steal
from her grave.

Type 990; **Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. XX 353; XXX--XXXII 127; *Hertel ibid. XXI 282.
Fire stolen by swallowing it and then escaping.

Plays all night for dance while confederate commits actual theft. Jamaica:
Beckwith MAFLS XVII 244 No. 21.
child:
Africa (Yoruba): Ellis 271 No. 6, (Nago): Basset Contes
populaires d’Afrique 217ff. No. 90.

content:
By
pretending that he has been invited to be godfather, the trickster makes an
opportunity to steal the provisions stored by him and the dupe for the winter.
When he returns on successive occasions he reports the name of the child as
“Just Begun,” “Half Done,” etc. *Type 15; BP I 9; Dh IV 241; *Krohn Bar (Wolf)
und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 74ff.; *Fb “ræv” III 113b, “bjørn” IV 43b; *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 238.--Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske
Eventyr III No. 3; French: Sébillot France III 63f.; Missouri French: Carrière;
Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 19; New Mexican Spanish: Rael Hispania XX
231--4; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 437; Africa: Frobenius
Atlantis III 13, (Fjort): Dennett 90 No. 23; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Remus 80 No. 17, Jones Negro Myths from the Georgia Coast (Cambridge, Mass.,
1888) No. 24, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 253--55, (North Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXX 192f., (South Carolina):
Parsons MAFLS XVI 7--12, JAFL XXXII 394, XXXIV 3; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 1;
Bermuda: Parsons JAFL XXXVIII 240.
child:
Trickster eats food left by tiger (his trapping partner) at
snare.

Tiger accused of the theft. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
The owner is duped by thief who gives him the task of
solving a riddle about the theft just accomplished.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1635*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1545*.

child: Thief cannot remember whom he delivered the goods to.

Though he has eaten the food trusted to him, he claims to
have delivered it, but cannot remember the person who opened the door. *Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 63.
Thief avoids detection by disguising as a woman.
Umpire awards his own stolen coat to thief.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525K*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1525 I*.
Stolen bacon offered to the owner.

Making off with bacon, thief accidentally enters farmer’s
living-room. Boldly says: “Master, the devil from hell sends you bacon.” The
farmer: “Take yourself off to hell with the bacon.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
1627B*.

Thief paints horse black on one side and leaves other side
white.

Hoodwinked guardians make
conflicting report of theft. Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
Husks replaced in granary so theft of grain is unnoticed.
Goldsmith as thief in king‘s treasury.

Makes golden human figure and says it is a corpse. Gets by
guards. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thieves escape detection by carrying woman on bier and
drowning her outcries with wailing.
Blame for theft fastened on inanimate objects.
Blame for theft fastened on fairies.

content: Thief loses his goods or is detected--miscellaneous.
child: Betrayal through exchange of stolen goods.

Thief claims that stolen goods are his own: detected by
master.

He has placed a coat on
the goods to be stolen. His associate changes the place of the coat. Chauvin II
83 No. 7; Bødker Exempler 273 No. 5; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Thief leaves food untouched when owner pretends to be
poisoned by it.

(Playing poison.) American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 54 No. 7, Nights 297 No. 50; Bahama: *Parsons
MAFLS XIII 122; West Indies: Flowers 511.

Sheep thief pretends to buy wethers from the ram, names the
price himself.

Owner overhears, takes the
ram to the thief to collect. U.S.: Baughman.

Robber induced to give respite and come to man‘s office to
get promised larger sum.

Tortoise asks greedy man to give him first ruby it has
given him to be sure second one will be perfect match: disappears into water
with it.
Owner pretends to think thief is family god and binds him.

Owner feigns madness and thus raises alarm: thieves
captured.

Hidden person sees robbers concealing treasure and takes
it.

Thief hides in large bottle to get into room: bottle put
into water to boil.

content:
Blind thief trying to steal dates from withered tree killed
by slipping of rope.

child:
Spending the night in
company with a suspicious-looking stranger, the man does not go to sleep, but
leaves his clothes in bed and waits to see what will happen. When the stranger
wakes up in the night, he stabs at his sleeping companion, who shoots him down.
(Cf. †K525.1.) Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 965*.
Robber with hand of glory killed.

A robber disguised as a beggar gets night‘s lodging at a farm
house. Using a candle made of human fat or hand of a corpse, he tries to charm
the household into a deep sleep (†D1162.2.1). One man who is suspicious and has
not gone to sleep sees this and kills the robber. Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
963*.

Man scares robber with sausage; later boasts of event at inn. Robber hears
this. Innkeeper secretly lends man a real revolver; robber is shot down when
boldly attempting a second attack. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 970*.
Conqueror of robber discovers his money-stick.

Thinking that he has killed the robber, the man takes his
stick or knife with big handle. The robber recovers and, disguised as a beggar,
inquisitively looks at the stick. The man is suspicious and by examining finds
much money inside it. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 962*; Russian: Andrejev No.
961 I*.

Youth told by two robbers to go to town and sell bracelet for each. He goes and
offers to sell two slaves. Goes back with buyer and cries out “Did you say
both?” “Yes.” Youth is paid; robbers are enslaved. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Clever girl discovers robber and cheats him.
child:
The girl seizes the robber concealed under the bed by the
beard and says: “What a coarse bundle of flax.
I need a finer one.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 959A*.

Disguised robber in night-lodging tries to pull up
confederate on rope: princess discovers him and catches him.
Girl tells the thief money is in chest.

When he looks in chest, girl drops lid on him. Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 959C*.

content:
U.S.: Baughman; West Indies: Flowers 509f.; Jamaica:
*Beckwith MAFLS XVII 235 No. 4, 239 No. 10.
child: Husband makes rhymes about cakes wife has stolen.

content: Person being robbed deceives robbers and calls help.
child:
Clever woman being robbed makes excuse for screaming and
summoning help.

Clever husband being robbed induces wife to make outcry and
summon help.

Owner pretends to help burglars to divide booty: handles
weights so loudly that police are summoned.

content:
Thief steals pig. Slaughters it together with one of his
own and takes both to market. Puts little pig inside large one to avoid paying
tax on two. Boy notices three hind legs. Thief is caught. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Mouse’s tail in mouth of sleeping thief causes him to cough
up swallowed magic ring.
Thief ties owner‘s hair while he escapes with goods.

Type 1166**; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Graham; N.
A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 303 n. 109b; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 278,
(Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 52 No. 6, (Wakweli): Bender 63; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 61 No. 12.
child: Owner frightened from goods by report of approaching enemy.

Owners frightened away from goods by report of deadly
epidemic.

Poor parson thus rids himself of
unwelcome guests; they leave food they have brought. *Wesselski Arlotto II 217
No. 81.

Thieves steal pig and make it impersonate person with
plague.

Owner and family flee. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Trickster quarrels with owner of goods, feigns death, and
frightens owner away.
Owner frightened away from goods by a bluff.

Dupe, made to believe that trickster becomes a wolf when he
yawns three times, flees and leaves his clothes behind him.

Porcupine, made to believe that rabbit‘s ears are horns,
flees and leaves food behind.

Africa
(Nuba): McDiarmid Sudan Notes and Records X 229f.
Owner frightened from goods by apparitions of the dead.

When they are turned
loose in the churchyard the parson and the sexton think that they are the souls
of the dead. Meanwhile the thief steals from them. *Type 1740; *BP III 388;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda (†K2334).
Thief frightens priest as the latter crosses cemetery.

Meanwhile a confederate steals his chickens. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Owner frightened from goods by trickster’s ferocious animal.

Pretended dog is really a lion. Africa (Ila, Rhodesia):
Smith and Dale II 388 No. 14.

Thief frightens away guards of his father‘s corpse by
impersonating demons.

Town crier is frightened by the voice of a cleric robbing a
grave.
Delivery boy is frightened into giving up his chickens.

Trickster upturns his eyelids and puts on boar’s tusks.
Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Trickster lights torches and bluffs old woman into giving
him money.

Torches alleged to belong to
man coming to collect damages from her. India: Thompson-Balys.
Servants frightened by ferocious actions of robbers;
give up masters‘ food. Pierre Faifeu No. 13.
Owner frightened away by thief disguised as devil.

Owner frightened from goods by trickster’s summons of wild
buffalo herd.

Trickster steals the
goods. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 211 No. 428, 215 No. 446; Missouri
French: Carrière; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
Frightened robber leaves his coat behind.

Chauvin II 83 No. 5;
Bødker Exempler 273 No. 6.
Object falls on robbers from tree.

They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys; Korean:
Zong in-Sob 144, 147 No. 64.
Door falls on robbers from tree.
Cow-hide falls on robbers from tree.
They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Person falls from tree on robbers.
They flee and leave money. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Robbers frightened from goods by the dead.
Corpse thrown among robbers frightens them from treasure.
Robbers frightened from goods by sham-dead man.
Robbers frightened from goods by man’s outcry.

Trickster hits a slain ox and cries out, “Those others did
it!” The thieves flee and leave their treasure. Type 1525D; India:
Thompson-Balys.

Animals climb on one another‘s backs and cry out; frighten
robbers.
Robber frightened from his goods by playing of bagpipe.
Robbers frightened from goods by hidden man.
Thieves steal chest containing hidden paramour.

Are frightened away by his outcry. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Robbers frightened from goods by Thumbling.

They can hear him but cannot see him. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Other thieves come to steal the bees, take the heaviest hive to the
forest and make a fire under it. They flee when they hear a man screaming in
the beehive. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1887*.
Guardian beast overcome by hero’s mirrors.
Robbers frightened from goods by man in tar and feathers.

Robbers coming to steal from stable frightened away by bear
staying the night there with his keeper.

Tricksters threaten to cook a robber. All the robbers flee
in terror, leaving them their booty. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 967*.

Sons of thief frightened by threatening to bring the three
strongest men to punish them.

Thieves frightened by ghosts who tie fruits to their hair,
which they think are missiles thrown at them.

content: Owner gives up goods through flattery.
child: The raven with cheese in his mouth.

The fox flatters him into singing, so that he drops the
cheese. *Type 57; *Basset RTP VI 244 n. 4; Crane Vitry 172 No. 91; Wienert FFC
LVI 52 (ET 121), 97 (ST 115); Halm Aesop 204; *Chauvin III 76 No. 49; Jacobs
Aesop 202 No. 8; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17 No. 11. -- Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 29 No. 12.

Goat induces the camel to talk and meanwhile eats all the
food.

content:
Oversalting food of giant so that he must go outside for
water.

Meantime his goods are stolen.
*Type 328; *Fb “salt” III 148b; Icelandic: Boberg.
child: Thief sends owner for water in leaky basket.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 87.

content:
House filled with smoke so that owner gives trickster
lodging.
child: Fire set to village so that robbers can steal goods.

Trickster fills house with smoke so that partner cannot see
to eat.

content:
Missouri French:
Carrière; India: Thompson-Balys; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 350; Cook Islands: Beckwith
Myth 270; West Indies: Flowers 503.
child:
The man claims to sleep thus and beguiles the ogre into sleeping, so as to rob
him. Type 1140*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1140.
Owner put to sleep and goods stolen.

Magic or drugs. Dickson 63, 67 n. 13, 68 n. 15; Irish
myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 107; Finnish: Kalevala rune 42; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 3/1142).

Master thief puts watchers to sleep and cuts off their
hair.
Theft after putting owner to sleep by lousing her.
Master thief puts guards to sleep and steals meat.

Guards fatigued by trickster so that they sleep while goods
are stolen.

Worthless object (animal) substituted for valuable while
owner sleeps.

Mouse‘s tail in mouth of sleeping owner causes him to cough
up magic object.

India: Thompson-Balys;
Africa (Kordofan): Frobenius Atlantis IV 134ff. No. 13.
Trickster steals magic doll while owner is asleep.

The foolishly concealed money: A man hangs a bag of money
in the top of a high tree.

Servant sleeping
with him steals it. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1858*.

Thief lies down in the space between the king‘s and the
queen’s bed and steals jewelry from both.
Man gulled into giving up his clothes.

N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 332 n. 199 (occurs in most
versions).

content:
India: *Thompson-Balys; Oceanic (New Zealand, Tahiti, Mangaia, Hawaii,
Melanesia, Micronesia, Indonesia): Dixon 46, 59, 65; Maori: Clark 160; Hawaii:
Beckwith Myth 230; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (T-G. 3/931).
child:
A blind
man’s arrow is aimed for him by his mother (or wife) who deceives him into
thinking that he has missed his aim. She eats the slain game herself. Cheremis:
Sebeok-Nyerges; Eskimo (Greenland): Rasmussen III 78, 202; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 354 n. 278.

Theft from three old women who have but a single eye among
them.

The hero seizes their eye. *BP IV
112 n. 5; *Frazer Apollodorus I 155 n. 4.

Buzzard steals coyote’s eyes, while he is throwing them up
in the air.

N. A. Indian (Klikitat):
Jacobs U Wash II 36.

Blind beggar overheard telling that his money is kept in a
stick.
Theft by giving narcotic to guardian of goods.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 225.

content: Owner persuaded that his goods are spoiled.

(Cf. †K355.) Bødker
Exempler 292 No. 50; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 123 No. 23.
child:
Trickster gives a woman a knife to cut him a slice of white
bread.

He gets the whole loaf when he says
that he has just cut a dog with the same knife. Type 1578*.

Servant places his one fish with Brahmin‘s entire catch; receives all since
Brahmin considers all polluted. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Servant eats all of master’s anchovies. When master asks for some, the servant
brings in a covered dish, and tells him that the fish smell very bad. The
master tells the servant to throw them away. Spanish: Childers.
Trickster cuts up partridges with his knife.

He is given all of them when he tells his companions that
he is an executioner. Spanish: Childers.
May take it all. India: Thompson-Balys.

Dupe persuaded that the dung has spoiled the field. He
gives the field to the trickster. Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 25 No. 2.

Son-in-law steals father-in-law‘s pants by making latter
believe he has dirtied them.
Sympathetic helper sent for remedy and robbed.

Africa (Benga): Nassau 86 No. 4, (Thonga): Junod 221,
(Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 386 No. 12.
Thief sent into well by trickster.

A weeping boy tells a
passing thief that he has lost a silver cup in a well. The thief takes off his
clothes and goes after the cup, intending to keep it. He finds nothing. When he
comes up, his clothes have been stolen. Hdwb. d. Märchens I 346a n. 126; BP III
392f.; Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 502), 106 (ST 183); India: *Thompson-Balys.
Dupe left to care for child while his goods are stolen.

Antelope sends leopard for fire, eats game while leopard is
gone.

Africa (Kiyansi): Van Whig
Biblioteca Africana IV 52.

content: Thief successfully claims that stolen goods are his own.
child:
Grain-thief’s wagon falls into ditch: duped owner helps
him.

The thief makes the owner believe
that the grain belongs to the thief. Type 1564*.
The stolen pot pawned with the real owner.

The thief gets a receipt from the owner and thus defends
himself when accused of theft. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 823; cf. No. 860.

Thief successfully claims that stolen image has been given
him by the saint himself.

content:
Thief escapes by leaving animal’s severed tail and claiming
that the animal has escaped and left his tail.
child:
Thief
steals animals and sticks severed tails into the ground, claiming that animals
have escaped underground. *Type 1004; BP III 392 n. 1; *Fb “hale” I 537, “svin” III 676a; Icelandic:
Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 1004; Missouri French: Carrière; Louisiana Creole:
Fortier MAFLS II 110 No. 2; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 241; Africa (Vai): Ellis 249 No. 41; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Remus 98 No. 20, Nights 230 No. 39, 241 No. 41, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII
368, (South Carolina): Parsons MAFLS XVI 31f., JAFL XXXIV 8; Bahama: Cleare
JAFL XXX 228; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 252 No. 29; Cape Verde Islands:
Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 n. 2, 113.

The thief kills one ox and puts the tail in another ox’s
mouth: the owner thinks one ox has eaten the other. Type 1004; *BP III 392 n.
2; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525G*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV No. 1525G*;
Russian: Andrejev No. 1525G*.
Stolen sheep‘s tails severed and put in tree.

Owner made to believe that they have escaped through the
air. *Type 1004.

content:
Accused of eating the lamb’s heart, the thief maintains that it had no
heart. *Type 785; *BP II 149, 153; Wienert FFC LVI 40, 107; Oesterley No. 83;
Herbert III 205; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 57; Penzer V 130 n. 1; India:
*Thompson-Balys.
child:
Accused of eating the goose‘s leg, the thief maintains that it had no leg, and
cleverly enforces his point by showing geese standing on one leg. (Usually the
master confounds the rascal by frightening the geese so that they use both
legs) *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 229 No. 75; Boccaccio Decameron VI No. 4
(*Lee 177); Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2424*; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. No. 191;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 508.
Thief maintains that the bird had no tail. Africa (Kaffir): Theal 184.

The ass as toll-gatherer is killed by the lion for asking for toll. The fox
eats the ass’s heart. When the lion asks for it, the fox replies that the ass
could have had no heart since he was such a fool as to ask the lion for toll.
**Keidel “Die Eselherz Fabel” Zs. f. vgl. Litgsch. n. ser. VII No. 58; Gaster Exempla 229 No.
244; Penzer V 130 n. 1; *Chauvin II 99 No. 58; Bødker Exempler 299 No. 63;
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys.

content: Blame for theft fastened on dupe.

*Penzer IV 191f. n. 1; Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 6 (Lee
257); Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 129.
child:
Thief accuses his companion of having stolen the gold they
have both stolen.
Dupe’s food eaten and then blame fastened on him.
Trail of stolen goods made to lead to dupe.

The crane in revenge for
the loss of her young ones strews pieces of fish from the dwelling of the
mongoose to that of the snake. The mongoose follows the trail and kills the
snake. *Penzer V 61 n. 3; Bødker Exempler 287 No. 37; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Stolen goods taken to dupe’s house so that he is accused.

Icelandic: Boberg;
Bødker Exempler 303 No. 74; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Greek: Frazer Apollodorus
II 178 n. 1 (Palamedes); Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 100.

Crow causes serpent to try to swallow a stolen collar and
thus be accused of the theft.

Chauvin II
87 No. 23; Penzer V 47 n. 3, 214, 226f.

Necklace dropped by crow into snake’s hole leads men to
kill snake which had eaten the crow‘s fledglings.

Bødker Exempler 281 No.
25; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Surreptitious transfer of stolen object to innocent
person’s possession brings condemnation.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 349, 892.
Stolen goods left in suitor‘s room.

Impoverished lover falsely accused so as to be rid of him.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Thief makes believe that he has been robbed of money
entrusted to him.

Thief successfully accuses owner of having stolen property
he covets.

content: Theft of gold hoard by spying on secret hiding place.

Thief pretends to return grass that has stuck to his
clothes to ground where it belongs.

Thief learns location of dupe’s food supply by strewing
ashes.

Fills the dupe‘s bag with ashes and
cuts a hole in the bag. Africa (Benga): Nassau 155, 204 Nos. 19, 32, (Ekoi):
Talbot 57, 62, (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 51 No. 6, 83 No. 13; Jamaica:
*Beckwith MAFLS XVII 248 No. 24; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 12ff.
No. 2.
child:
Girl made to carry shell from which ashes fall: she is thus
followed.

content: Theft by use of coat of invisibility.
Thief feigns illness to be taken in victim’s house.

(Cf. †K341.2.2.1.)
Ransacks it while “recovering.” Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Pickpockets strike man on leg so that he takes his hand off
his purse.
Tricksters feign death of their father.
Collect rent and flee. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Trickster pollutes house so that he is left in possession.

He is in upper room and
throws filth on those below (Cf. †K344.) American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Nights 26 No. 6; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 84, Edwards MAFLS III 74; West
Indies: Flowers 504.
child: Trickster pretends to have spit in wine accidentally.
Is allowed to drink it. Korean: Zong in-Sob 104 No. 56.

content:
Trickster asks hospitality: expels owner and appropriates
house.
child:
Crow asks hospitality of sparrow and gradually takes
possession of nest and kills young.

(Often
told of camel and tent.) India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Trickster claims to be working magic spell over food and
eats it. India: Thompson-Balys.

Trickster advises wife to slaughter pig and have the
trickster eat it all. Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 252 No. 30.
Trickster permitted to try on clothes.
Goes away with them. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 727.
child: Trickster persuades tailor to leave his goods.

Makes him believe he
will get order to clothe fifty poor. Trickster makes away with goods. (Or tries
on boots and makes away with them.) Nouvelles Récréations No. 23; Pierre Faifeu
No. 21; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Thief borrows cloak so to carry food.
Trickster permitted to try on ornaments.
Goes off with them. Cook Islands: Beckwith Myth 445.

content: Means of hoodwinking guardian or owner--miscellaneous.
child: Theft by means of magic invisibility.

Thief beguiles guardian of goods by assuming equivocal
name.
Thief of sweetmeats says his name is Fly.

Child shouts to father, “Fly is eating,” etc. “Never mind
the fly, guard against the cow.” India: Thompson-Balys.
Trickster dupes woman into putting him into basket.
He thus learns where food is kept. India: Thompson-Balys.

Crow makes friends with pigeon so as to be able to steal
food in household to which he belongs.
Objects stolen by means of magic impersonation.

content: Signal for theft given in foreign language.
Owner bids on his own goods at auction.

Rival buyer pays extravagant price. *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin II 204 No. 405; Chauvin VIII 107 No. 83.
Eavesdropping sexton duped into giving suppliant money.

The trickster prays to the Virgin for a certain sum of
money and promises repayment of double at the end of the month. The sexton
throws the money to him, but never receives it back. Type 1543*.
*BP III 36; Chauvin V 245 No. 147; Japanese: Ikeda.
child: Courtesan runs away with men’s goods.

Thieving contest: first steals eggs from under bird; second
meantime steals first‘s breeches.

Steal from each other.
(Cf. †K306.) Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Youths execute a series of clever thefts.

content:
An impostor feigns to make clothes for the emperor and
says that they are visible only to those of legitimate birth. The emperor and
courtiers are all afraid to admit that they cannot see the clothes. Finally a
child seeing the naked emperor reveals the imposture. *Type 1620; **Taylor MPh
XXV 17; *Chauvin II 156 No. 32, VIII 130 No. 120; *Wesselski Gonnella 133 No.
33; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: God to reveal self to those of legitimate birth.
All afraid to admit not seeing God. India: Thompson-Balys.
Whoever hears singing snake must die.

Killed by deaf man. (Cf.
†B214.1.10.) Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 145.

content: The heller thrown into others’ money.

A rascal sees robbers dividing their booty. He puts a red
string through his only coin (a heller) and slips it into the others‘ money. He
claims the money as his and says that he has marked it with a heller having a
red string through it. The robbers divide. *Type 1615; *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin II 197 No. 387; Chauvin V 254 No. 151 n. 2, VII 153; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 566.
child:
Trickster drops half a grain into grain cellar then demands half of the grain
supply. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Two thieves steal a ham
from a former companion who has married, have it stolen back, and resteal it.
(Cf. †K341.7.1, †K362.4.) *Gering Islendzk Æventyri (Halle, 1883) II 210ff.;
*DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal; en Letterkunde XLV 213ff.

Thief
robbed of his booty. Scotch: Campbell-McKay No. 27.
Man is robbed of gold chain while with prostitute.

He swallows her string
of pearls in revenge. (Cf. †K302.1.) Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Blind man steals from neighbor who in turn steals from him.

content:
The lawyer tells the butcher that the dog‘s owner (himself) is liable
for damages. He ask double the amount of the damages as fee. Type 1589.

Counselor accuses conspirators in order to confiscate their
estates.

He confesses that he has an oversized measure and agrees
to get a smaller one. He measures back the grain in the smaller measure. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 146 No. 1800B*.
Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 159 No. 31, (Ekoi): Talbot 387.
child:
Thief (abductor) returns and enforces reward. *Type 575;
*BP II 131.

Trickster gets money from a bank by raising an alarm and
demanding “what is owing to him.”

Host with overstock of sour wine spreads rumor of dragon at
his house.

A crowd gathers and he sells
all his wine. *Wesselski Morlini 309 No. 65.
False alarm of robbery causes cheated man to be imprisoned.

Boccaccio Decameron IX No. 4; Italian Novella: Rotunda;
Persian: Lorimer Persian Tales (London, 1919) 321 No. 52.

content:
Color of devil’s cows changed while he sleeps so that he
does not know them.

Only those not changed
(all black, all red, etc.) belong to the devil. Dh I 188; Lithuanian: Balys
Legends No. 134.
Money received to bury sham-dead person.
child:
Husband and wife each receive money (from different
persons) to bury the other, who is supposed to be dead.

Trickster reports treasure‘s owner dead: receives it from
children.

content:
Demi-coq by means of his magic animals and magic water
collects money.
child:
Blackbird to avenge capture of his wife carries rope, club,
cat, ants and river in ears.

content:
Fox covers his head with milk and says that his brains have been knocked out.
Frightens bear. *Type 3; Dh IV 243; Krohn Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 59ff.;
Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 287; American Negro (Georgia):
Harris Nights 21 No. 5, 377 No. 68.

In cooking dinner fox‘s porridge is light, bear’s black. At dinner fox
steals spoonful of bear‘s porridge and lets bear taste it. Bear believes that
fox’s
porridge is as bad as his own. *Type 9 C; Dh IV 249ff.; Krohn Bär (Wolf) und
Fuchs (JSFO VI) 97ff.
Cheating by substitution of worthless articles.
child:
Prometheus divides slain ox so that bones and entrails
seem to be choicest part. (Zeus is not deceived.) Greek: Fox 13.
Rock substituted for ham by trickster.

Tortoise cheats leopard by substituting bundle of resin for
bundle of meat.
False articles used to produce credit.

Nugget of supposed gold (lead) given to help build church:
money then borrowed.
Reward for the bag of lead.

A man sews up lead in a bag and feigns to have found it. A
merchant claims it and thinking it filled with gold pays him a large reward.
*Wesselski Bebel I 204 No. 83.

Wine-casks partitioned: one half wine, other half water. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Innkeeper serves sweetened water for wine, cat for rabbit,
mule for beef.
False set of rings to offset genuine.

Jewels bought with counterfeit money. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Priests substitute gilded images of calves for those of
solid gold.

While swimming with the lizard, toad exchanges own ugly
daughter for lizard‘s pretty one.
Lean geese substituted for fat by trickster.

Woman gives friend dried comb while she herself eats the
honey.
Cheating by substitution of common cow for magic one.
Audience secured with the pope by rudeness.

A woman bribes a man to get her an audience with the pope.
By turning his back to the sacrament and saying that the woman had instructed
him to do so, he brings it about that she is summoned into the presence. *Pauli
(ed. Bolte) No. 347.

Entry into enemy’s presence by pretending to be a messenger
from a relative.

content: Trickster cheats rescuers into digging his well.

The well that he has dug falls in. He throws his clothes
into the hole and hides. People going to church think that man is drowned and
dig the well out. Type 1614*.

Köhler-Bolte I 513;
Breton: Sébillot Incidents s.v. “équivoque”; India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
The thief hands it to his confederate. He says, “I haven’t
it.” The confederate says, “I didn‘t steal it.” Wienert FFC LVI 84 (ET 505),
103 (ST 162); Halm Aesop 301.

Two prisoners are made stable boys on their promise not to escape secretly.
Before horse race starts they ask: “Do we have your leave to go?” They go home.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Why go all the way to fair?

Man robbed of his plate of cakes half way to fair asks
another vendor, “Why go to the fair, when half way up people come demanding
your plate?” Vendor goes on and meets with same fate. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
The peasant weighs the butter which he is selling to the
baker along with the bread which he is buying. Type 1566**.

child: One thief hides in money bag; other carries it off.
One thief entrusted with other thieves‘ money cheats them.

content:
Woman has husband made monk while he is drunk, so as to get
rid of him.

Scala Celi 87a No. 506; Crane
Vitry No. 231; Liebrecht 124; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 38; Spanish
Exempla: Keller.

(Lai
of the Tresses.) A woman leaves her husband’s bed and has another woman take her place.
The husband addresses her, gets no answer and cuts off her nose (hair). In the
morning the wife still has her nose (hair). The husband is made to believe that
it has grown back by a miracle (or that he was dreaming). *Type 1417; Bédier
Fabliaux 228ff.; Chauvin VI 100 No. 267; *Penzer V 47 n. 3, 223ff., VI 271;
Mensa Philosophica No. 40; Boccaccio Decameron VIII No. 8 (Lee 222); Cent
Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 38; Bødker Exempler 280 No. 24; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child:
A chaste wife substitutes a maidservant for seducer. A
finger and ring are cut off as proof of wife‘s unfaithfulness (chastity wager
with husband). Refuted by husband, who knows they are not his wife’s. Cf. Type 882;
Köhler-Bolte I 375; Child V 497 s.v. ”Substitution“; Wesselski Märchen 213
No. 19; Irish myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 110.

content:
Adulteress makes believe that her suspicious husband is
insane.

He is taken away. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Trickster as sham magician buys chest containing hidden
paramour.
child: Sham magician has paramour fall in a trap.

Has trained bird to cling to him. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Trickster discovers woman‘s paramour and hides him in
outhouse: rewarded by husband.

content:
Wife takes servant‘s place and discovers husband’s
adultery.

The husband says that he is
going into a state of meditation with a cloth over his face. He substitutes a
servant and goes to his mistress. The wife finds the deceit and takes the
servant‘s place. On his return the husband tells the supposed servant of his adultery.
Japanese: Anesaki 361.
Second lover burns paramour at window with hot iron.

*Type 1361; Chaucer’s Miller‘s Tale; *Thompson The Miller’s Tale (Bryan and
Dempster 106ff.); Italian Novella: Rotunda. See references for †K1225.

The wife makes the husband, who has seen the adultery from the tree, believe
that the tree is magic or that he has seen double. *Type 1423; *F. N. Robinson
Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer (Boston, 1933) 817 (Merchant’s Tale); *Basset 1001
Contes II 150ff.; Chauvin VIII 98 No. 69, IX 39 No. 34; *Bédier Fabliaux 468;
*Stiefel Zs. f. Vksk. VIII 79; *Wesselski Märchen 214f. No. 23; Crane Vitry 240
No. 251; Herbert III 21; *Wesselski Mönchslatein 121 No. 103; Hdwb. d. Märchens
I 95b; Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 9 (Lee 231); Dunlop-Wilson II 120f.; Mensa
Philosophica No. 76.--Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child:
Husband who has surprised wife and paramour is made to
believe that he has had an illusion.

content: Woman warns lover of husband by parody incantation.

(Cf. †K1961.1.2.1,
†V66.1, †X441.) Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 1 (Lee 185); Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
child: Woman warns lover of husband by singing song.

content: Husband in disguise begs food of his wife‘s suitors.
Husband unwittingly instrumental in wife’s adultery.

(Usually shares his bedmate with others, not knowing that
she is his wife.) Heptameron No. 8; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 9; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child:
Not knowing lover’s identity, husband takes him to his
wife and entrusts him to her care. He then leaves on a trip. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

content: Wives wager as to who can best fool her husband.

*Type 1406; *Liebrecht
124; Bédier Fabliaux 265ff.; *Crane Vitry 227 No. 231, cf. 238 No. 248;
Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 9 (Lee 231); Christensen DF XLVII 229; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.
Husband frightened by wife’s paramour in hog pen.

The husband sees the paramour who has hidden in the pen
and says, ”Who are you?“ ”I am a miserable hog.“ The husband thinks that his hogs are
possessed. (Cf. †K1515, †K1555, †K1566, †K1574.) Wesselski Bebel I 206 No. 92;
Spanish: Espinosa III No. 193.
The marked coat in the wife‘s room.

A procuress obtains a
woman for her client by leaving a marked coat in her room. The husband drives
the wife away and she joins her lover. The procuress then goes to the husband
and alleges that she lost a coat with certain marks. The husband is deceived
and takes the wife back. *Bédier Fabliaux 443; **Eberling Auberée,
altfranzösische fabel etc. (Berlin, 1891); Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Sexton’s own wife brings her offering.

The priest grants to the sexton the offerings brought by
all women whom the priest has loved. The priest always calls out ”Take“ when
these women offer. The sexton‘s own wife comes. The priest calls out ”Take!“ (Cf. †Q384.) Wesselski
Bebel I 185 No. 40.

child:
After seducing priest’s wife, peasant demands earrings as
price of silence.

He thus avenges himself
on priest who has cheated peasant‘s wife of her earrings. Russian: Andrejev No.
1726**.

content: Husband duped by paramour into taking his wife to him.

**J. W. Spargo FFC XCI; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of
Geoffrey Chaucer 838a. (Shipman‘s Tale).
child: Lover’s gift regained: the broken (removed) article.

The lover breaks (or removes) an article of household
equipment and convinces the husband that for that reason the wife has
confiscated that which he gave her as a present. **Spargo FFC XCI.
Lover‘s gift regained: horse and wagon as gift.

The lover regains gift
of horse and wagon by pretending to the husband that the wife has confiscated
them because he brought wood of uneven quality. **Spargo FFC XCI; *Erk-Böhme
Deutscher Liederhort (Leipzig, 1893--94) I 40ff.

Lover’s gift regained: borrowing from the husband and
returning to the wife.

The lover borrows
money from the husband with which to corrupt the wife, later telling the
husband that the money was returned to the wife during the husband‘s absence.
**Spargo FFC XCI; Boccaccio Decameron VIII Nos. 1, 2 (*Lee 247ff.); F. N.
Robinson Works of Chaucer 838a (Shipman’s Tale); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Lover‘s gift regained: accidental discovery of identity.

The lover, ignorant of
the identity of the husband, tells him of his experience with the wife. The
husband persuades the lover to lead him to the scene, where the wife is
compelled to restore all but a small part of the money. *Spargo FFC XCI;
*Euling Studien über Heinrich Kaufringer (Breslau, 1900) 65ff.; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.
Lover’s gift regained: piece of cloth as gift.

The lover regains by a ruse and thievery the borrowed
piece of cloth which he has presented to his mistress. **Spargo FFC XCI.

Lover claims payment for cloth in the presence of the
husband.

The woman returns the cloth but
puts a live coal in it. Destroys his whole supply. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Lover demands return of cloth on threat to await the
husband‘s return.
Lover’s gift regained: jewelry as gift.

The lover presents the wife with a valuable piece of
jewelry, which he regains by pretending to the husband that he has left it as a
pledge. **Spargo FFC XCI; *Wesselski Bebel II 115f. No. 49; *Bolte Frey 242 No.
76.
Lover‘s gift regained: anser venalis (goose as gift).

The lover regains his
gift by a ruse (obscene). **Spargo FFC XCI; *Semerau Die Schwäke und Schnurren
des Poggio (Leipzig, 1905) No. 69; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Lover delays the gift of the goose hoping to obtain greater
favors.

Finally has to flee. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Lover’s gift regained: refusal to leave bed.

Woman fearing exposure returns money. Cent Nouvelles
Nouvelles No. 178; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Lover‘s gift regained: spending money to purchase lover’s
worthless goods.
Lover‘s gift regained: payment with worthless money.

Lover bargains with the husband. Pays him with worthless
money. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Husband gets gift which paramour has given to wife.

content:
Paramour feigns loss of genitals in order to obtain the
husband’s confidence.

Cent Nouvelles
Nouvelles No. 13; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Adulteress uses the public baths as a meeting-place with
her lover.

A naive remark by her child
exposes the deception to the husband. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 66; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

Innocent confessor duped into being go-between for
adulteress and lover.

By following
suggestions in her false accusations to confessor the lover reaches her side.
Boccaccio Decameron III No. 3 (Lee 71); *Borgeld Vrouwenlist: verbreiding en
oorsprong van een novelle uit den Decamerone (Neuphilologische Bibliotheek No.
7, Den Haag, 1926); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

child: Woman has paramour steal her husband‘s clothes.

Paramour gains entrance disguised as the husband. The
husband without his clothes is driven away from his home. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Wife surprised in adultery feigns death.

Comes ”back to life“ on hearing husband say he has seen nothing. (Cf. †K1538.) Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Lover carried away on mistress‘s shoulders so that his
footprints will not be visible in the snow.

Lover leaves horse outside house as husband comes up: wife
tells husband their cow has foaled a horse.
India: Thompson-Balys. Cf. English, Scottish: *Child No. 274.

Unfaithful wife communicates with lover by pouring milk
into stream.

Wife’s attendants on trip chase wrong man as suspected
lover and miss real lover.
Husband deceived as to noise made by hidden paramour.

content: Adulteress falls in mud at lover‘s door.
The Lord above; the lord below.

A husband returning home surprises a woman and her
paramour and a numskull who has blundered in. The woman hides the numskull in
the bed and the paramour under it. The husband, who is leaving on a journey,
lifts his hands to heaven and says, ”I commend you to the Lord above.“ -- The
numskull: ”Commend her rather to the lord below!“ *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 271 n. 1,
Bebel II 99 No. 2, Morlini 286 No. 30; *Bédier Fabliaux 453; Rumanian:
Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1380 II*; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 34; Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Friar‘s trousers on adulteress’s bed: relic to cure
sickness.

The husband is duped into
believing that the friar has come to visit the sick. *Bolte Frey 248; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

Husband
deceived by adulterous wife. Irish myth: Cross.
child: Cuckold feigns to be asleep when paramour calls.

content:
The husband returns unexpectedly to find his wife
entertaining the paramour with a sumptuous feast. He is made to believe the
feast is in honor of some newly-weds. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Husband in hanging tub to escape coming flood.

The priest who has thus duped the husband enjoys the wife.
*Type 1361; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of Geoffrey Chaucer (Boston 1933)
786b (Miller‘s Tale); *Hammond Chaucer: a Bibliographical Manual 275; *Barnouw
”The Miller’s Tale van Chaucer“ Handlingen van het 6. nederlandsche
Philologencongres (1910), Mod. Lang. Rev. VII 145; *Thompson in Bryan and
Dempster 106ff.

(Inclusa.) Woman goes
from one to the other. Her husband is made to believe that the woman next door
is her sister. *Fischer-Bolte 219; Wesselski Märchen 188 No. 2; *Chauvin V 213
No. 121, VIII 96 No. 67; *Köhler-Bolte I 393; Campbell Sages cx; *Krappe
Archivum Romanicum XIX (1935) 213--226; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 1;
Icelandic: *Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
The husband meets the paramour in the wife’s place.

Beats him (or cuts off
privates). *Wesselski Bebel II 149 No. 161; Nouvelles Récréations No. 60; N. A.
Indian (Malecite): Mechling GSCan VI 83 No. 21, (Fox): Jones PAES I 145.
child: Husband hides in wife‘s room and kills paramour.

content:
The wife sends her maid
to investigate. The maid falls in and finally the wife herself. The husband
calls the neighborhood to see them. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 9 No. 4; Cent
Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 56; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Husband proves intrigue by secretly blacking paramour’s
mouth.

When he returns, his wife‘s face is
black. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 863.
Blades (broken glass) to wound and detect wife’s lover.

(Often on window.) Type 432; *Krappe Balor 35ff.;
*Schoepperle I 218ff.; Irish myth: Cross.

Cuckolded man shuts wife‘s paramour in chest and lies on
the chest with latter’s wife.

Boccaccio
Decameron VIII No. 8 (Lee 261); Italian Novella: Rotunda.
child:
Cuckold unwittingly lies with wife on chest containing her
hidden paramour.

content:
Husband tricks wife into riding a mule which has been
denied water.

On fording a stream the mule plunges into the water. Wife drowns.
(Sometimes also paramour.) Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 47; Nouvelles
Récréations No. 90; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Husband outwits wife and paramour--miscellaneous motifs.
child:
Surprised paramour pays. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 43;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Rebukes them for not shutting the door. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 71.
Illness feigned to go to mistress.

Husband leaves bed to go to serving maid. Italian Novella:
Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.

Beats or otherwise discomfits wife. Cent Nouvelles
Nouvelles No. 65; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Husband catches paramour by using wife’s pre-arranged
signal.

Husband persuades wife to light wicks and carry knife in
hand before committing adultery: lovers frightened away.

Husband pretends that his wife‘s privates tell him of her
adultery. India: Thompson-Balys.

Husband discomfits paramour and wife by clever remark
showing that he knows all.

Wife persuades him he has killed thief. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
Trickster makes woman believe that her husband is coming to
punish her adultery.

She confesses. *Type
1725; BP II 131; Christiansen Norske Eventyr 136.
Trickster sends his master running after the paramour.

Though the master does not know of the adultery, the lover
is thoroughly frightened. *Type 1725; BP II 131; Christiansen Norske Eventyr
136.

Woman excites peasant (secretary), who draws line on floor
and dares her to cross it.

When she does,
adultery is committed. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 23; Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Complacent in all except kissing. Explains that her mouth is the only part of
her body which has promised fidelity to her husband. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles
No. 48; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Student extends his course so as to enjoy the professor‘s
wife.

Faithful wife in disguise saves husband from punishment for
adultery.
Seventy tales of a parrot prevent a wife‘s adultery.

The parrot keeps her interested until her husband’s return. *Schmidt Cukasaptati
(Kiel, 1894, Stuttgart, 1896); Köhler-Bolte I 47, 336, 513; Clouston Tales II
196ff.; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 59 No. *435.
child: Faithless wife kills magic parrot which has betrayed her.
Peacock left as spy on adulterous wife.
Dog guards chastity of master’s wife during his absence.

content: Adulteress disguised as boy elopes with paramour.

Paramour sends prostitutes in disguise to take mistress to
”convent“.

Husband is deceived by the
ruse. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child:
The wife pretends to treat his one good eye, so that he
cannot see the paramour. *Chauvin IX 20 Nos. 7, 8; Alphabet No. 535; Scala Celi
86b No. 504; Oesterley No. 122; Hitopadesa (ed. Morley) 66; Mensa Philosophica
No. 49; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 27; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Physician treating man‘s eye covers his one good eye.

Entertains his patient’s mistress. Cent Nouvelles
Nouvelles No. 87; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Girl covers nurse‘s one good eye so that she cannot see her
lover.
Adulteress extinguishes light to hide her paramour.
Adulteress covers husband’s eyes during incantation.

Meanwhile paramour escapes. Italian Novella: Rotunda;
India: Thompson-Balys.

Adulteress persuades husband to milk cow with his eyes
blindfolded: meets lover.

The faithless wife asks her gullible husband how he would
act if he were blind.

The husband closes
his eyes; meanwhile the lover escapes. India: Thompson-Balys.

Wife washes husband‘s hair hiding his eyes while lover
escapes unseen.

Wife has husband look for hole in pot she has bought,
allowing lover to escape unseen.

Wife shows husband her milk-filled breasts and squirts milk
in his eyes allowing lover to escape unseen.

content:
Trickster discovers adultery: food goes to husband instead
of paramour.

*Types 1535, 1725; *BP II 18; von der Hagen III *xxix; Wesselski
Märchen 216 No. 27; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1360A*, 2901*, 2902*; Rumanian:
Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1380 VIII*; Russian: Andrejev 1360A*, 1730 IV;
India: *Thompson-Balys.
child:
Trickster discovers adultery: gets food prepared for
paramour.

Trickster as sham magician makes adulteress produce hidden
food for her husband.

*Type 1535; BP II
18; Scala Celi 37a No. 206; Japanese: Ikeda.

content:
Husband returns home secretly and spies on adulteress and
lovers.
child: Husband returns secretly and kills unwelcome suitor.

Adulteress detected: husband secretly drops dye on her
dress.
Adulteress detected by food she prepares for paramour.
India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 341.

content:
Husband feigns blindness and avenges himself on his wife
and her paramour.
child: Husband feigns illness to surprise wife with paramour.

content: Husband (god) traps wife and paramour with magic armor.
Husband carries off box containing hidden paramour.
child: Dying woman lures paramour into chest.

Asks husband to bury chest with her. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Chest containing paramour unwittingly taken away by
husband.
Lover hidden in hen-coop discovered by husband.

Boccaccio Decameron V No. 10 (Lee 173); Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

The naked lover hides himself in a sooty barrel. The husband receives from a
curious gentleman a good sum of money for showing him the ”devil“. Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 2900*; Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

content: The husband sets house afire and ousts hidden paramour.
Type 1406*; von der Hagen II *xxxvi No. 41.
child:
Trickster sets fire to barrel of tow in which paramour is
hidden.

The paramour, naked, runs out
carrying wisps of burning tow. The trickster tells the husband that he has
raised the devil. England, U.S.: *Baughman.

content: Husband discovers wife‘s adultery by riddling conversation.

In this indirect manner the wife confesses and promises
reform. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 122 No. 1358*.
child:
Husband discovers paramour’s love letter in his wife‘s
purse after having made her drunk.

content:
Hidden cuckold reveals his presence by rhymes. He responds to the
rhymes made by the wife and paramour concerning their entertainment. *Type
1360C; **Anderson Der Schwank vom alten Hildebrand (Dorpat, 1931); *BP II 373;
Hdwb. d. Märchens I 188a nn. 164--5; Spanish: Espinosa II No. 93, III No. 193.
child:
Adulteress binds husband‘s eyes and causes him to sing
incantations concerning the adultery.

content:
She suspects the fraud
and persuades him that she knew the ruse and was testing him. He begs
forgiveness. Bédier Fabliaux 290, 453*; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

*Type 1364; *Wesselski
Märchen 187 No. 2; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Paramour placed in chest and covered with clothing.

When husband comes in she drops candle and sends him out
for another, allowing lover to escape unseen. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Lover escapes behind the sheet which wife holds up to show
her husband.
Husband busied with performing task while paramour escapes.

content:
Adulteress transforms her husband into an animal to get rid
of him.
child: Adulteress transforms man to stone up to the waist.

content:
God Vishnu in shape of nephew scares and torments his
aunt‘s lover.

(Tristan and Isolt.) Husband goes to wife’s love tryst and
hides behind a tree. The wife, having learned of his presence, tells lover that
he should not allow their innocent relations to lead to gossip. Husband is
appeased. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

child: Adulteress tells her lover how she loves her husband.
Adulteress tells how she may save her husband‘s life.

Discovering him under the bed, she tells lover that at
temple she has learned that her husband is to die soon unless she prevents
death by sleeping with a strange man. The husband is satisfied. Benfey
Panchatantra II 258ff., Panchatantra III 12 (tr. Ryder 348).

content: Husband transformed to goat must witness wife’s adultery.

The devil has let him see his wife‘s unfaithfulness in
this way. Type 824*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 824*; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV
No. 824*; Russian: Andrejev No. 824*.
The husband prepares to castrate the crucifix.

The artist’s wife‘s paramour poses as a crucifix when
caught. When he sees the husband’s preparations, he flees naked. *Köhler-Bolte II 469; Spanish:
Espinosa II No. 42; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.
Adulteress gets rid of husband while she entertains lover.
child: The husband in the chicken house.

The husband returns
unexpectedly and surprises his wife with her lover. She makes the husband
believe he is pursued and hides him in the chicken house. (Cf. †K1514.9.) *Type
1419A; **Schofield Sources and History of the 7th Novel of the 7th Day in the
Decameron (Harvard Studies and Notes II); Bédier Fabliaux 450; Boccaccio
Decameron III No. 4 (Lee 213); Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 88; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys.

Husband duped into doing penance while rascal enjoys the
wife.

Boccaccio Decameron III No. 4 (Lee
75); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Husband duped into believing he is in purgatory.

Boccaccio Decameron III No. 4 (Lee 91); Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

Mistaken for lover whom he has told them to beat. Von der
Hagen II xiii No. 27.

Husband, dressed in wife‘s clothing, is beaten by
forewarned paramour. The latter says that he is testing the wife’s fidelity to
her husband. Spanish: Childers; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Husband hides in curtain to catch paramour.

On entering, paramour threatens to kill husband if he
should appear. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 4.
Husband hides in chest to catch paramour.

(Cf. †K1566.) Cent
Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 27; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Adulteress locks up hidden husband and meets lovers.
Wife has hiding husband carried off in basket by thieves.

Wife throws husband down precipice so she can be with
lover.
Adulteress has lover unload wood on doorstep.
This keeps husband out. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Adulteress sets husband to watch for intruder while she
entertains the paramour.
Illness feigned to call physician paramour.
Adulteress pretends to go to say her prayers.
Keeps tryst with paramour. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Adulteress gives paramour tryst in house of ill-fame.

Meets husband who leaves in shame. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.

Husband chases mare while the wife entertains the paramour. Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Adulteress throws small coffer out of window.

While the husband retrieves it the paramour changes hiding
places. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Lover masks as pregnant woman: adulteress sent by husband
to act as midwife, meets lover.
Adulteress together with lover while husband sleeps.
Wife drugs husband and visits paramour.

Adulteress has servants impersonate demons. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Adulteress makes excuse to go and attend to bodily needs:
meets lover.
The lovers as pursuer and fugitive.

The wife is visited by
two gallants. When the husband approaches, one goes out with drawn sword; the
other hides in the house. She convinces her husband that she has given refuge
to a fugitive. *Type 1419D; *Bédier Fabliaux 229ff.; *Basset 1001 Contes II
143; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 186 No. 351; *Chauvin VIII 39 No. 7, IX 21
No. 8; Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 6 (Lee 203); von der Hagen II xxxii ff;
Dunlop-Wilson II 114ff.; Hdwb. d. Märchens I 99b. -- Spanish Exempla: Keller;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India:
Thompson-Balys.
One lover disguised and carried out of house by other.

The wife has the lover put on a robe and stand in the
corner; she tells the husband that a tradesman has left the robe and will
return for it. The other lover comes and she gives him the ”robe“. Africa
(Vai): Ellis 229 No. 38.
Boccaccio Decameron VII No. 3 (Lee 189); Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Paramour in vat: disguise as vat-buyer.

Husband thinks he is testing the vat. Boccaccio Decameron
VII No. 2 (Lee 186); Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Lover hidden in chest with feathers.

Husband believes he is a
devil. (Cf. †K1218.1.) J. Prinz ”A Tale of a Prioress
and her Three Wooers“ Literar.-Hist. Forschungen XLVII (Berlin, 1912) 65ff.,
113ff.; Hilka Compilatio Singularis Exemplorum No. 14.

Husband thinks he is a demon. Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No.
72; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

When surprised with the wife he tells the husband that he
has been trying to force the woman, with no success. The wife supports the
statement. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Paramour disguised as cloth merchant is surprised by the
husband.

He asks the woman to be paid for
a pretended sale. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Paramour leaving love-tryst is met by husband.

Pretends he had come to see him on business. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Paramour escapes by pretending to be returning borrowed
basket.
Escaping paramour said to be a deity.

Adulteress refuses to admit husband under pretence that he
is a stranger.

*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 678;
Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 1.

Wife of philanderer gets revenge by having an affair
herself.

content:
A husband insists that his wife take oath that she has been
intimate with no one but himself. The paramour masks as ass-driver. She hires
an ass from him, falls down, and lets him pick her up. She then swears that no
one has touched her except her husband and the ass-driver. *Type 1418; *Basset
1001 Contes II 4; **J. J. Meyer Isoldes Gottesurteil in seiner erotischen
Beziehung (Berlin, 1914); *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 206; Rohde Der griechische
Roman 484; BP IV 154, 387f.; Hdwb. d. Abergl. II 669; *Schoepperle I 225f.;
Hertel Zs. f. Vksk. XVIII 385. -- Icelandic: Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Chavannes 500 Contes I 387 No. 116.

Meetings in the grave
(grave box). *Wesselski Märchen 197; *Child V 3f., 6, 280; *Pauli (ed. Bolte)
No. 876; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 305 n. 109t.
child: Wife feigns death and slips out to lover.
Death feigned so man can live with mistress.

content:
Fox threatens to catch bird, who feeds him her young as
appeasement.

He threatens to push down
tree or to fly. Type 56A; Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.
Wages: as much as he can carry.

To get rid of the boy the troll offers him as large wages
as he is able to carry. Boy says that this will be too much, that he will be
contented merely with what the troll can carry. Type 1153.
Threat to build a church in hell.

Bluff: wealth gained by seeming to be in the king’s
confidence.

Courtier asks the king for a
reward that will cost nothing. He gets permission to listen to the king‘s devotions. He now
receives bribes because of his apparent influence. *Penzer V 186 n. 1; *Wesselski
Mönchslatein 127 No. 110, Morlini 266 No. 4; Clouston Tales II 360ff.; *Herbert
III 421 No. 82; Scala Celi 136b No. 762.

Shoemaker offers to trim the peasant’s feet to fit the
shoes.

The peasant prefers to accept the
ill-fitting shoes. *Bolte Frey 217.

Herdsman threatens invasion with enormous herds: bought
off.

He hires himself as herdsman of all
his master’s flocks for ten years. He then sends notice to surrounding peoples
that he is coming with his master‘s flocks to graze. They bribe him to stay
away. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 362.
child:
Trickster falsely reports impending invasion from his own
people.

Receives money to buy them off.
India: Thompson-Balys.

Adventurer on otherworld island sees great hornless oxen
guarded by giant: tries to frighten them.

”Why dost thou frighten the stilly calves?“ says the huge herdsman. ”Where are
the dams of these calves?“ asks the adventurer. ”They are on the other side of
yonder mountain,“ said he. So he went thence. Irish myth: *Cross.

content: Miracle must wait till one man is sacrificed.

No one volunteers and it
does not need to be performed. *Wesselski Mönchslatein 118 No. 99.

Host serves many rare vintages and gets a reputation for his wine
cellar. But there is only a small jug of each vintage. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
837.

Man falsely claims to have killed elephant with his flat
hand.
Bluff: insult repeated as harmless remark.

The trickster makes an insulting remark, but when called
on to repeat what he said he changes it so as to turn aside wrath. Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 130; Africa (Basuto): Jacottet 12 No. 1, (Benga): Nassau
153ff. No. 19, (Yoruba): Ellis 266, (Ibo, Nigeria): Thomas 88, 151, (Kaffir):
Theal 165, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 384 No. 10, 395 No. 18; West
Indies: Flowers 545. Cf. Chaucer Nun‘s Priest’s Tale lines 343ff.

King persuades men to follow him, pretending that he is
going to make peace with his brothers, instead battle.
Ogre made to believe small hero is large: overawed.

India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 245;
Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 359 No. 12.
child:
Tiger made to believe porcupine bristle is his enemy‘s
hair: overawed.

India: *Thompson-Balys;
Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 90; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 53.

content: Big shoes in front of the barn.

Man makes giant shoes and places them so that ogre thinks
a giant lives there. Type 1151.
Hare as ambassador of the moon.

Hare claiming to be
ambassador of moon shows elephant the moon irritated in a spring. Elephant is
persuaded that the moon is angry. *Penzer V 101 n. 1; Chauvin II 96 No. 49;
Panchatantra III 2 (tr Ryder 308); B[ö]dker Exempler 294 No. 54; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys.

Weak animal (man) makes large one (ogre) believe that he
has eaten many of the large one‘s companions.

The latter is frightened. Types 126*, 1149; *BP I 160 n. 1; *Krappe
Neophilologus XV 274ff.; Russian: Andrejev No. 126; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos.
249f.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: *Dixon 191 nn. 15, 16, 192 n. 17;
Africa: Weeks Jungle 394, Werner African 223, (Kaffir): Kidd 230 No. 2, (Vai):
Ellis 191 No. 7, (Hottentot): Bleek 24; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV
(1) 317, 320, 322; West Indies: Flowers 543; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Nights 44 No. 9, 291 No. 49.
child:
Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and frightens
him.

Tells him that this animal is
threatening to kill him. (Usually hare and lion.) *Penzer V 49 n. 1; Chauvin II
88 No. 25; India: *Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 134
No. 18, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 264 No. 12.

Weak animal shows strong his own reflection and makes him
believe that it is the head of the last animal slain by the weak.

B[ö]dker Exempler 282
No. 27; Indonesia, Malay, Hindu: Dixon 191 n. 16, *DeVries Volksverhalen I 362
No. 14.
Man shows ghost its own reflection and frightens it.
Man shows demon reflection and frightens him.
Bluff: only one tiger; you promised ten.
The wolf flees from the wolf-head.

The sheep have found a sack and a wolf-head. They make the
wolf believe that they have killed a wolf, and he flees in terror. *Type 125;
BP I 237ff., 254; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 249f., 255f., 266; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Africa (Wakweli): Bender 54.

Enemies frightened away by making them think they will be
eaten.

Chauvin V 23 No. 13 n. 1; Spanish:
Espinosa III Nos. 255f., 266.

Spirits frightened away by making them think they will be
eaten.
Leopard frightened away by report of lizard’s presence.
Lizard has bitten leopard before. India: Thompson-Balys.

Trickster pretends to hunt certain tree with which his
ancestors have killed tigers.

Bluff: small (lame) hero makes demon believe he is a god
and threatens to eat him.

Bluff: hero to brother, ”You take one and I can manage the

--”I am glad, for I don’t like

His wife has killed it and he has fled. India:

The master thus gains a reputation for wealth. Spanish:

”House of my father with one hundred fifty lights and goat pen.“ When the

says wooer as he strokes his whiskers. The girl thinks he is indicating the

child: Sham physician cures people by threatening them with death.
Man undertakes to cure fat abbot of stomach ailment.

Novella: Rotunda.
Patients frightened from hospital by harsh treatment.

Catch the flea, open its mouth, and place the powder
inside. Pierre Faifeu No. 18; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 133 No. 1550A*; Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

A king wants his daughter to grow up quickly. The
physician says that he must send away for the medicine; meantime she must be

Noodles 102; *Penzer V 91 n. 1.
The sham physician and the devil in partnership.

Cheat: demon kills people so his pupil can resuscitate them
and get reward.

Ignorant youth buys a medical degree.

Sham physician hands out prescriptions haphazard.

content: Brother (sister) secures blessing due to another.

Impostor: one sister borrows another‘s clothes and gets
religious blessing in her place.

content:
Wise man sent by king to rival to give him interested
advice.
Impostors claim reward (prize) earned by hero.

miracle-producing relic.

tricksters questions its powers in public. Feigns being struck dead. Feigned
resurrection. Tricksters enriched as a result. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

content:
Sham miracle: may the grass grow up! Tricksters who have
done no mowing say to their master when he angers them, ”May the grass grow up

content: Living man at the grave pretends to be dead man speaking.

answers.

content:

Sowing grain: does so in unplowed field.

earth, the trickster uses the carcasses of cattle. *Type 1005.
Trickster deceives dupe into killing his own children.
Master’s mother killed: wood heaved on her head.
Caring for the child: child killed.

31; S. A. Indian (Mataco): Métraux MAFLS XL 133.

taken out and cleaned. Type 1012; India: Thompson-Balys.

victim.

Animal perishes. *Boje 72ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys; Easter Island: Métraux
Ethnology 365; Africa (Nyang): Ittman 58.

Escape by substituting brother for intended victim, namely
self.
Exchange of clothes between master and his servant.
Two rival parties of fifteen each on ship.

When food is exhausted, it is agreed that half the company
be thrown overboard, “every ninth man as they stood to be selected.” Clever
sister of leader of one party arranges men so that enemies are chosen and so
drowned. Irish myth: *Cross.

Man calls animal by his son’s name so he can sacrifice it
instead of his son.
Escape by dressing in animal (bird, human) skin.
Man sewed in animal‘s hide carried off by birds.
Escape by dressing in bear’s skin.

Þiðriks saga I 261--72
(cf. 339--40); Asbjørnsen and Moe No. 58 (type 590); Gonzenbach No. 68 and Köhler‘s notes.
Escape by putting on old woman‘s skin.
Change of bodily appearance so as to escape.
Disguise by shaving off beard so as to escape.
Disguise by mutilation so as to escape.

Ears cut off, eyes put out, etc. *Chauvin VIII 136 No.
132; Africa (Basuto): Jacottet 24 No. 2.

Disguise as king with mask in order to hide from enemy who
has ruined warrior’s face and torn his beard off.
Disguise as farmer so as to escape.
Disguise as carpenter so as to escape.

Disguise by painting (covering with soot, etc.) so as to
escape.
Covering self with clay so as to escape.
Clothes changed so as to escape.
India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 8.
Disguise in clothes of other sex so as to escape.

*Chauvin V 96 No. 31 n. 1; Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9
(Lee 54); Icelandic: Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Man in danger of life dressed by hostess as woman and set
to baking.

Man in danger of life dressed by hostess as woman and set
to grinding corn.

Man in danger of life takes his wife’s place in the bed
with her night-cap on.
Disguise as musician in order to escape.
Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 396 No. 18.

Musician in danger puts on his musician’s attire as if
about to play; escapes.
Escape by disguising as a washerman.
Disguise as waiter in inn to escape.
Adulteress escapes prison disguised as an old woman.

Escape by making sheaths of bark for fingers: hero leaves
without awakening nymph wives who make him sleep with fingers in mouth.

Abbot escapes from his paramour’s husband in disguise of
priest.
One animal escapes by shamming as another (jackal as goat).
Goat escapes from jackal by being covered with flowers.
Women escape from enemy‘s camp disguised as ascetics.
Hare escapes lion by being bundled in brushwood.

Hare and bride travel in pot to escape tiger, answer
“Ruined pot” when challenged.

child: Death feigned to escape unwelcome marriage.

(Cf. †K523.0.1.)
*Chauvin V 134 No. 63; *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XXI 284; Child II 355--367, III 517,
IV 482ff., V 234a, 296b; *Wesselski Märchen 198; Lithuanian: Balys Index No.

Escape by shamming death: blood and brains.

The trickster covers himself with paint (or the like) so
that he will be thought to have bled to death (or with milk so that it will be
thought that his brains have been knocked out). *Type 3; Dh IV 243; Krohn JSFO
VI 55ff.; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 329 n 191a; Africa (Kaffir): Kidd 242
