Woman covers fleeing man with placenta of goat and with
blood to convince pursuers she has just given birth and thus prevents their
capturing him.

“He smells already.” Type 1139; cf. Indonesian:
Coster-Wijsman 52 Nos. 77, 78.
Death feigned to escape from husband‘s death plot.

Captive parrots in net play dead and are thrown out:
escape.

Fisherman ignores him.
Bødker Exempler 283 No. 28; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
wrecked boat or coffin lands. Icelandic: *Boberg.

trickster
attacked by angry mother causes her to spear ox guts and believe she has
murdered him. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Maori: Clark 167; Africa (Zulu): Callaway 78, (Angola):
Chatelain 99 No. 6.
child:
Illness (madness, dumbness, etc.) feigned to escape
unwelcome marriage.

Illness feigned to escape rendezvous with undesired
mistress.
Illness feigned to escape unwelcome meeting.

content:
An ordeal (usually dangerous) is escaped by
deceptively providing a substitute. English: Hibbard 71, Wells 158 (Amis and
Amiloun); Icelandic: Göngu Hrólfs saga 274ff.; N. A. Indian (Arapaho): Dorsey
and Kroeber FM V 74 No. 37; West Indies: Flowers 512.
child:
The
hero is compelled to smoke a fatal pipe, but the helpful insect which he
carries on his head smokes the pipe for him. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 330
n. 191c.
Escape by substituting self for another condemned to die.

Holy man substitutes self for deacon held by heathen.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Two wicked men put to a fiery test ask for a third (pious)
man to be tested together with them.

content: Throwing the thief over the fence.

Thief, surprised at theft says: ”Do your worst, only don‘t
throw me over the fence.“ When thrown over, he escapes. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 1627A*.
Punishment which proves fatal to captor.
child:
Turtle persuades an animal to swallow him: causes the
animal’s death and escapes.

content:
After debate it is decided that marriage is the greatest
punishment. Wesselski Bebel II 103 No. 15; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 35 No. 165*.
child:
Thief begs for any punishment except the luxury of two
wives.

content: Animal ”punished“ by being placed in favorite environment.
child:
By expressing horror of
drowning, he induces his captor to throw him into the water --his home. *Type
1310; *Dh IV 43; Köhler-Bolte I 266; *Fb ”ål“ III 1190b; England: Baughman; Danish: Christensen DF
XLVII 171; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Dixon 195, 196 n. 32, *DeVries
Volksverhalen II 360 No. 107; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 443, (Tinguian):
Cole 196, 197 n. 1; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 302 n. 108; Africa (Angola):
Chatelain 153 No. 17, (Jaunde): Heepe 107; (Benga): Nassau 124 No. 12, (Ibo,
Nigeria): Thomas 88, (Yoruba): Ellis 266 No. 3, (Zanzibar): Bateman 40 No. 2;
American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 58 No. 12, 115 No. 24, Friends 167 No.
23, cf. Harris Nights 61 No. 12; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 236 No. 5; West
Indies: Flowers 516.

By expressing horror of
being thrown into the briar patch he induces his captor into doing so. He runs
off. **Ruth I. Cline American Literature II 72ff.; **Espinosa JAFL XLIII 129
ff.; *Dh IV 26; Köhler-Bolte I 266; *Parsons Folklore XXX 227. Missouri French:
Carrière, Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 108; Indonesia: *DeVries
Volksverhalen II 381f. No. 147 (duck); Oceanic: Meyer Mythen und Erzählungen

Men double up hare‘s legs and throw him on the ground as
punishment.
Bird punished by being thrown into air.
Birds caught in net fly away with it.

He
expresses horror of that punishment. Sets fire to village from his burning
tail. Why he has burnt tip on tail. India: *Thompson-Balys.

Thieving insect put in closely woven basket asks to be put
in a loosely woven one so he cannot see.

content: One animal saves another by frightening enemy away.

Confederate sings and delays pursuers so that fugitive
escapes.
Free animal saves its captured friend.
child: Crow and rat release deer from snare.

content: Monkey saves condemned birds through feigned dream.

Monkey attracts attention of mowers until young birds can
fly away from the harvest field.

Japanese:
Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 82.

Confederate cuts rope almost in two so that prisoner breaks
it and flees.

Scottish: Campbell-McKay No. 15; Korean: Zong in-Sob 22,
212; N. A. Indian (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 31.

Falsified order of execution. A messenger is sent with a letter ordering the
recipient to kill the bearer. On the way the letter is changed so that the
bearer is honored. *Types 428, 930; *Aarne FFC XXIII 69ff., 91; *BP I 282; *Fb
“brev” IV
61ab; *Chauvin VIII 143ff. Nos. 145ABC; *Cosquin Études 143ff.; Gunkel Märchen
im alten Testament (Tübingen, 1921) 132; *Boje 79; *Penzer I 52, II 113f., III

271.--Icelandic: Hdwb. d. Märchens I 326 nn. 16-26, Herrmann Saxo II 262ff. I,
*Boberg; Greek: *Frazer Apollodorus I 151 n. 2; Jewish: Neuman; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 828; Japanese: Ikeda; Africa:
Frobenius Atlantis IV 290.
child:
Death evaded by persuading executioner that another victim
was ordered.

(E.g., boy has been ordered
to kill hare. Hare persuades the boy that the father said, “Kill the rooster
for the hare.”)
Africa (Nyika): Bachmann ZsKS VI 84f., Meinhof Afrikanische Märchen 95ff. No.
18, (Namwanga): Dewar Chinamwanga Stories (Livingstonia, 1900) 57ff., (Kaffir):
Alexander und Mohl Mitt. d. Sem. f. Orient. Sprachen VIII 15ff. No. 5.

Ogam inscription on shield orders that bearer (who does not
know meaning) shall be killed.

Poet (who
recognizes the meaning) reports to king that inscription means a request for
honorable treatment. Irish myth: *Cross.

content:
A servant charged with killing the hero (heroine) arranges
the escape of the latter. Icelandic: *Boberg; English: Wells 96 (Chevalere
Assigne); Irish: MacCulloch Celtic 74; Italian: Boccaccio Decameron II No. 9
(Lee 56), Basile Pentamerone II No. 6, III No. 2; Italian Novella: *Rotunda;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 95 No. 53.
child:
Slaves charged with killing (drowning) the infant heroine
are touched by her “laughing smile” and put her in a calfshed (hollow tree),
where she is found by cowherds, who rear her. Irish myth: *Cross.

Executioner persuaded to let hero go. India:
Thompson-Balys.

A servant charged with killing the hero smears the
latter‘s coat with the blood of an animal as proof of the execution and lets
the hero escape. *Cox 475; *Boje 62, 66; Icelandic: *Boberg; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda.

Compassionate executioner: bloody knife (sword) from slain
animal substitute.

A servant charged with
killing the hero (heroine) substitutes an animal, whose heart he takes to his
master as proof of the execution. *Types 671, 709; *Böklen Sneewittchenstudien
79ff.; *BP I 450ff., 463; *Aarne FFC XXIII 57, MSFO XXV 181; *Prato RTP IV 178;
Chauvin V 208 No. 120; *Cox 474; *Saintyves Perrault 68; Fb “hjaerte” I 631a, “lever” II 404b, “tunge” III 894a.--Icelandic:
Boberg; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC No. 706C*; Missouri French: Carrière; French
Canadian: Sister Marie Ursule; India: Thompson-Balys; Jewish: Neuman (†S350);
Chinese: Graham; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian (Shuswap): Teit JE II 730 No.
50; S. A. Indian (Quiche): Alexander Lat. Am. 172.

Compassionate executioner: substituted brains (other animal
for helpful animal).
Eyes of animal substituted as proof for eyes of children.

Eyes, ears, fingers of corpse substituted for those
demanded of victim.
Animal substituted for child served at meal.

BP III 137 (Grimm No.
141); English: Wells 96 (Chevalere Assigne), Alphabet No. 593; Italian: Basile
Pentamerone V No. 5; S. A. Indian (Yuracare): Métraux BBAE CXLIII (3) 503.

The servant charged with sending the hero to executioners
sends his own child instead. *Boje 63 n. 1; Jewish: *Neuman; Japanese: Ikeda.
Executioner makes substitution when victim escapes.

Compassionate executioner: substituted head (made of clay)
as proof of execution.

Compassionate executioner: mutilation substituted for
death.

Boy’s sixth toe cut off by compassionate executioner as
proof he had been killed.
Compassionate executioner: feigns to torture victim.

Compassionate executioner: sleeping potion supplied instead
of poison.
Children hidden to avoid their execution (death).
Girl escapes by hiding in huge harp.
Sleeping persons covered with oxhide and so saved.
Escape by hiding in the earth.

content: Disguise as girl to avoid execution.

*Oesterley No. 156; *Herbert III 133 No. 117; Icelandic:
Anssaga Bogsveigis (FAS II) 359; Greek: Roscher Lexikon s.v. “Achilleus”; N. A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 313 n. 128; Africa (Ba Ronga): Einstein 260, (Zulu):
Callaway 40.
child: Girl substituted for boy to avoid slaughter by father.

content:
Watchman outwitted by having rope stretched across the road
while fugitives escape.

Captive plays further and further from watchman and
escapes.

Africa (Kaffir): Theal 33,
(Basuto): Jacottet 102 No. 15; West Indies: Flowers 519.
child: Escape by pretended debate as to which must be judged.

Jackals thus induce leopard to permit them to enter their
cave, while he waits in vain. India: Thompson-Balys.

Escape from captor by throwing objects to great distance
which captor tries to procure.

India:
Thompson-Balys; Africa (Wute): Sieber ZsES XII 172.

Wife accused of plan to escape weeps and threatens suicide
so as to allay suspicion and escape.

Monkey in danger on bridge of crocodiles pretends that the
king has ordered them counted.

India:
Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Anesaki 317, Ikeda; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 7,
Dixon 190 n. 10.

Escape from robbers by pretending to be going the same way
but separating at the first opportunity.
Escape from pursuers by pretending to be one of them.
Monkey saved from trap by feigning marriage.
Chinese: Graham; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 6.
Respite while captor acts as umpire between captives.
Wolf acts as judge before eating the rams.

They are to go to the
end of the field and run to him. They run at him and kill him. *Wesselski
Märchen 251 No. 58; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 30, 31.
Tiger to help foxes divide their young.
Foxes escape into hole. India: Thompson-Balys.

Knight is refused permission to leave city. He rushes to
city gates and pretends that he has just killed a public enemy. Is aided in his
escape. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Thief is
jailed for stealing a quarter of veal. Sends man named ”Calf“ to captor. ”I
took only one quarter of veal, but I am sending you a whole calf.“ Is set free.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
A plea for a larger audience.

Fox asks cock to come down from a tree and sing for him.
Cock asks fox to awake his companion, a dog, first. Dog kills fox. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Escape by throwing money (treasure) so that guards fight
over it.

content: Escape by giving narcotic to guards.

Boje 112ff.; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India:
Thompson-Balys.
child: Escape of girl foiled by hero‘s refusal to take narcotic.

Type 306; Africa (Ronga): Junod Les Chants et les Contes
des Ba Ronga (Lausanne, 1897) 317ff. No. 30.
Escape by making the watchmen drunk.

Irish myth: Cross
(†K649.1); U.S.: Baughman; Icelandic: *Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Abductors tricked into running race while captive escapes.

Escape by asserting that captor will have ill luck after
killing victim.
child:
Escape by asking girl about to murder him if she will have
to assume all the guilt.

content: Escape from captor by means of flattery.

child: Escape by pretended bathing of guard.

Man and woman escape by sending the she-bear to bring the
woman’s ”forgotten“ comb.
Tiger enticed away to gather berries: victims escape.
Tiger enticed away by slain pig.

content:
To get out of thieves’ clutch, man reports high prices in
another town.

Escape by false prophecy: if corpses are buried in city, it
will become a ruin: king releases condemned man.
Man allowed to pick out tree to be hanged on.
child: Escape by asking to die falling from a tree.
Man asks to be beheaded standing in tank of water.

He ducks and executioners kill each other. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Prisoner kills his watchers who enter to torture him.
Fox climbs from pit on wolf‘s back.

*Type 31; Wienert FFC LVI 52 (ET 119), 97 (ST 117); Halm
Aesop No. 45; Jacobs Aesop 220 No. 82; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia,
Indo-China: *Dixon 189 n. 9, cf. DeVries’s list No. 4.

Wolf descends into well in one bucket and rescues fox in
the other.

*Type 32; BP IV 320; Chauvin
III 78 No. 57; Fb ”ræv“ III 113b; *Krappe Bulletin
Hispanique XXXIX 43; English: Wells 184 (The Fox and the Wolf); Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; American Negro (Georgia): Harris

child: Captive dodges when captor tries to cut off his hand;

The captor is thus induced to fire all his shots. Type
1528*; BP III 455; U.S., Scotland: Baughman.
Person holds hat just outside shelter; enemies shoot at it,

either giving away their position or putting themselves at
a disadvantage in having to reload. U.S.: *Baughman.

content: Mice gnaw enemies’ bow strings and prevent pursuit.

*Fb ”bue“ IV 76b; Jewish: *Neuman; N. A. Indian (Hupa):
Goddard U Cal I 154ff.
child:
Army of mice save kingdom from enemy invading force by gnawing
their provisions, ammunition, etc., to shreds.

content:
Captor‘s powder is removed, ashes substituted: gun does not
discharge.
Escape by arranging captor’s clothes so as to delay him.
child: Escape by throwing captor‘s clothes on the fire.

Master thief persuades captors to dive into water: steals
their clothes.

content: Sleeping enemies’ hair tied to an object prevents pursuit.

Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian (Hupa): Goddard U Cal I
154ff.
child:
Hair of sleeping maiden tied to tree so that she is not
able to rise.

content: Holes bored in enemies‘ boats prevent pursuit.

*Hdwb. d. Märchens I
552a n. 285; Herrmann Saxo 125; Kersbergen Literaire Motieven in de Njala
(Rotterdam, 1927) 83; Panzer Hilde-Gudrun; Icelandic: *Boberg; Indonesia: Van
Baarde Bijdragen voor Taal-, Landen Volkenkunde van Ned.-Indie VII (2) 464; N.

child: Paddles broken in enemies’ boat prevent pursuit.

content: Cutting thongs of sleds prevents pursuit.

Eskimo (Greenland): Rink 131, 448, 469, (Central Eskimo):
Boas RBAE VI 634, (Smith Sound): Kroeber JAFL XII 167.

Captive tied to captor escapes by tying end of rope to a
post.
Escape by persuading captor to talk.
child: Attempted escape by persuading captor to talk fails.

Animal captor persuaded to talk and release victim from his
mouth.

Usually cock and fox, fox and wolf,
or mouse and cat. *Type 6; *BP II 207; *Chauvin II 200 No. 39; *Fb ”ræv“ III 113b; **Dargan MPh IV 39; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 743;
*Graf FFC XXXVIII 39f.; *F. N. Robinson Works of Chaucer 858 (Nun‘s Priest’s tale).--Lithuanian:

Ikeda; Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 23 No. 12; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Nights 146 No. 27; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 326 No. 110;
Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 239f. No. 12.
Cat fails to be beguiled into releasing mouse.

The mouse tells the cat a tale. The cat answers at last,
”Even so, I eat you up.“ Type 111.

Frog escapes after telling crow to sharpen his bill before
eating him.
Sheep persuade the wolf to sing.

Dogs are summoned. *Type 122C; *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. IX 87;
Italian Novella: Rotunda; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Crocodile persuaded to open his mouth.

When he does, he shuts his eyes automatically and monkey
escapes. Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 853.

content: Rat persuades cat to wash face before eating: escapes.
child: Captive trickster persuades captor to pray before eating.

Escapes. Africa (Nama):
Bleek 23, No. 12, (Hottentot): Meinhof Lehrbücher d. Sem. f. orient. Spr. XXIII
165.

Hare persuades cat to perform two gallops before eating
him: escapes.

content: Escape because of plea that leaves means of egress open.
child:
Jackal in tiger‘s house has permission to sit with tail
hanging down between bamboo stems.
Enlarges gap thus made and escapes. India: Thompson-Balys.

Tortoise persuades tiger captor to put him in pocket with
hole, escapes.

content:
Thumbling in animal’s belly persuades latter to go to his
father‘s house for plunder: rescued.
child:
Boy swallowed by fish that is thrown up on shore persuades
tiger to cut it open with injunction not to look at him.

Jackal entrapped in elephant’s carcass tells passing God to
show his magic power by making it rain.
Elephant‘s hide swells; jackal escapes. India: *Thompson-Balys.

content:
Ass begs wolf to pull thorn out of foot before eating him:
kicks wolf in mouth.

Escape by pretending to perform errand (do work) for
captor.

Africa (Thonga): Junod 212,
(Kaffir): Theal 188, (Ekoi): Talbot 233; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Friends 60 No. 8, Nights 366 No. 65.
child:
Prince to giant: ”Don’t eat me up, and I‘ll prepare you a
good dinner.“

Man persuades robbers to postpone killing him until he can
show them his treasure.

Leads them into
marsh and escapes. India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
Cannibal sent for water with vessel full of holes: victim
escapes.
child:
Cannibal sent for water which magically recedes from him:
victim escapes.

New Zealand: Dixon 85,
Beckwith Myth 196 n. 19.

content: The three teachings of the bird (fox).

In return for release
from captivity the bird (fox) gives the man three teachings. These usually mock
the man for his foolishness in releasing what he has. (See for these counsels:
†J21.12, †J21.13, †J21.14.) *Type 150; *BP III 230, IV 149 n. 2; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 380; *Wesselski Arlotto II 261 No. 1191; *Chauvin III 103, 110ff.,
IX 30; *Crane Vitry 144 No. 28; *Gaster Exempla 256 No. 390; *Basset 1001
Contes II 276f.; Jacobs Aesop 213 No. 58; Wienert FFC LVI 35; Halm Aesop No.
271; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 95a; Alphabet No.
191; Oesterley No. 167.--Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas IV 29, 279; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 231.

Enemy in ambush (or disguise) deceived into declaring
himself.
child:
(”Hello, house!“) An animal suspecting the presence of an enemy in his cave
(house), calls and receives no answer. He then says, ”Don‘t you know, O cave,
that we have agreed that I must call you when I come from abroad and that you
in turn must answer me?“ The hiding animal answers and the other flees. **M.
Bloomfield JAOS XXXVI 58; Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 110; Mexican
Spanish: Espinosa JAFL XXIV 419ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys, Panchatantra (tr.
Ryder) III 15, 361; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 853; Indonesia: DeVries’s
list No. 31; N. A. Indian (Oaxaca, Mexico): Boas JAFL XXV 208; Africa
(Zanzibar): Bateman 41; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 142 No. 19;
Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 247 No. 23; West Indies: Flowers 517.

Crocodile masking as a log obeys suggestion that he move
upstream.

He thus betrays himself.
Indonesia: *DeVries‘s list No. 29, *Dixon 190 n. 12.
Crocodile in ambush betrays self by talking.
Sham-dead man deceived into making gesture.

Obeys suggestion as to how dead man should act and betrays
himself. U.S.: Baughman; India: *Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia):
Harris Remus 53 No. 11; West Indies: Flowers 517--9.
Sham-dead tiger betrayed by his live penis.
Sham-dead deceived into moving by absurd action.

Leopard concealed in bundle betrays self when threat is
made to run spear through bundle.

content:
Captive gradually moves away and at last escapes. Africa (Kaffir): Theal 109;
Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 137 n. 1.
child: Pursuer persuaded to sing while captive escapes.
Escape by teaching song to watchman.
India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 277.

Trickster, pretending not to see attacking enemy, sings
song of friendship.

Captor is compelled to dance while victims escape. Africa
(Gold Coast): Barker and Sinclair 100 No. 18.
Escape by singing watchmen to sleep.

Musician in hell playing for the devils, purposely breaks
fiddle strings.

Must return to earth to
repair strings. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3276, Legends Nos. 467--471.
Witch put off guard by playing on jew’s harp.
Escape by persuading captors to dance.

content: Escape by posing as member of murderer’s family or tribe.

India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Kaffir): Theal 130,
(Basuto): Jacottet 2 No. 1, (Fjort): Dennett 106 No. 30.
child: Escape by posing as preceptor of tiger’s deceased father.
Giants thus dissuaded. Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 3/1323).

content:
Escape by
assuming an equivocal name. (Sometimes ”myself.“) *Hackman Polyphemsage 179,
203, 219; *Fb ”selv“; Clouston Noodles 194 n.; BP III 378; *Oertel Studien zur
vgl. Literaturgeschichte VIII 117f.; *Toldo Zs. f. Vksk. XV
70.--Finnish-Swedish: Wessman 56 No. 480; India: *Thompson-Balys; Chinese:
Eberhard FFC CXX 262; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 36.
child:
Fairy child injured by man who says that his name is
”Self“.

Child tells mother, ”Self did it.“
England, Scotland: *Baughman.

Man has eaten sweets and says his name is B. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Executioner kept busy or interested until rescue comes.
Sometimes until he changes his mind.
child: Respite from death gained by long-drawn-out speech.

Respite from death gained by tale of the preparation of
flax.

*BP I 222; Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 365A*, Legends Nos. 349, 360.

Respite from death gained by tale of the preparation of
bread.

*BP I 222; 331; Rumanian:
Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 1199 I*.
Respite from death gained by long-drawn-out song.

Unsuccessful imitation.
(Cf. †Z20.) Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 364.
Escape by singing an endless song.

The soldier‘s bargain with Death. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 1084A*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1084 I*; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No.
1615*.
Tiger persuaded by jackals to settle argument.

content:
The man who has chosen
Death as his godfather has his bed turned around when he sees Death standing at
the foot of his bed. He thus escapes death. *Type 332; *BP I 377ff.; Wesselski
Märchen 214 No. 17; **Christiansen Danske Studier (1915) 72ff.; Icelandic:
Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII No. 332; Jewish: *Neuman; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda.

Respite from death granted until particular act is
performed.
child: Respite from death granted until prayer is finished.

It lasts till rescue comes. *Types 122A, 227, 332, 955,
1199; *BP I 381, 404ff., II 164; India: Thompson-Balys.
Respite from death granted until confession is made.
Respite from death until mass is said.
Herbert III 84, 508; Chauvin II 191; Icelandic: Boberg.

Respite from death until prisoner has finished drinking his
glass.
It is left half finished. BP I 381.

Iguana persuades jackal to let him go so he can finish his
drink.

Respite from death until victim has blown on a horn (three
times).

Rescuers come. *Types 592, 920; *BP II 501; *Wesselski Märchen 199; DeVries FFC
LXXIII 41ff., 324; *Thien Motive 36f.; *Child V 483 s.v. “horn”; India: Thompson-Balys.
Respite from death while one plays the fiddle.
Respite from death while captive plays music (whistles).

Rescue arrives. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 173; Wienert FFC
LVI 52 (ET 113), 99 (ST 127); Halm Aesop No. 134.
Respite from death while one sings song.
Three cries allowed maiden about to be murdered.
Wild boar given permission to squeal before wolf eats him.

Rescue arrives. *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. IX 87; *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 173; Rumanian: Schullerus FFC LXXVIII No. 91; India: Thompson-Balys.
Respite from death while one plays the bagpipe.
Respite from death while victim dances.

India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ndau): Curtis Songs and
Tales from the Dark Continent (Boston, 1920) 45ff.

Girl to dance for robbers asks to bring her party (strong
men in disguise) who overcome robbers.
Mare is allowed to dance before being killed;

it dashes off to jungle with persecuted boy hidden in
belly. India: Thompson-Balys.
Men ordered to dance before being killed.

Dance figure arranged so as to defeat captors. India:
*Thompson-Balys.

Titmouse receives permission to sit on branch and sing
before being sacrificed.
Respite from death until toilet is made permits escape.
Respite from death until clothes are changed.

Devil must wait for man to tie his stocking before the man
comes into his possession.

Robber insists on disrobing woman before
throwing her from precipice. She pleads to have him turn his face while she
disrobes. She pushes him off. (Cf. †K1645.) Italian Novella: Rotunda
(†K551.4.2).
Respite from death until hero bathes and drinks.
Escape by pretending to go to river and wash clothes.

Respite from death until mouth is washed; crow slain with
arrow as he goes to wash mouth.
Escape by pretending to go for bath.
Escape by pretending to return for hair ribbon.
Girl makes toilet and calls help.

When she sees robber under her bed she pretends not to see
him and combs her hair at the window. She says, “When I am married my husband
will come home from the tavern and seize me by the hair and I shall cry:
”Help!“ Rescue comes. Type 959*; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 959B*; Russian:
Andrejev No. 959*; Chinese: Graham.
Escape by asking to die on a horse.
Escape by asking to ride on sacred buffalo.
Captured animal asks respite while he gives war alarm.
Wolf kept at door until children have been christened.
Let me live as long as this candle lasts.

Man who has sold his
soul to devil thus escapes. (Cf. †G303.12.5.4.) Type 1184*; Irish: O‘Suilleabhain 36, Beal XXI 313.
Escape by asking a last kiss.

Uses the opportunity to attack adversary. Spanish: Boggs
FFC XC 30 No. 69*.

Ten (five) year respite given captive while he undertakes
to teach elephant (ass) to speak.

Captive
explains to friends that in that time the captor, the elephant (ass), or
himself is likely to die. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Respite from death until muddy victim may dry self in sun.
Respite from death until one pays a last visit.
Respite from death until visit is finished.

Respite from death until captive has taken six steps toward
God.

Takes prodigious ones and escapes.
Irish myth: Cross.

Respite from death until prisoner is healed by magic
object.
Woman escapes by ruse: must go to defecate.
Respite from death for drink of water.
India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 174 No. 75.
Kidnapped woman escapes by asking for drink of water.

Jackal persuades woman to untie his legs so that he may get
a drink.

Respite from death granted until wolf reads horse’s
passport.
Wolf kicked to death. (Cf. †J1608.) Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

Respite from death granted while wolf counts hairs in
horse‘s tail.

Wolf kicked to death.
Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

Wolf is requested by tailor to be measured for suit of
clothes; wolf beaten.

Respite from death until minister shows king how to reap
pearls.
A year’s time granted to settle affairs before death.

God grants man twenty years more of life provided he plays
no tricks.
Crocodile grants boy five days respite from death.

Escape by false plea: jackal asks to be able to clasp tree
before crocodile kills it.
Respite from death until hero climbs tree.

He flies away in machine stored there. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Escape from threatened captivity by pretending to send for
object for captor.
Turtle allowed to go to pool to pick flowers before death.
Respite from death until victim can fall asleep.

Captors give captive respite in order to witness alleged
marvel.

content: Escape by laughing and crying at same time.

Captured bird cries in thinking of her little ones and
laughs under pretext that the hunter is wasting his time instead of taking the
treasure which she pretends is in her house. The hunter leaves her. *Chauvin II
172 No. 2, V 135 No. 64 n. 1.

child: ”Wait till I am fat enough to race you.“

Hero to be eaten by cannibals when he is fattened enough
to beat them in a race. He runs away. India: Thompson-Balys.

Captured animal pretends to help captor bring more
desirable victim. Escapes. Chauvin II 116 No. 94; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Africa (Kaffir): Theal 188, (Basuto): Jacottet 40; American Negro (Georgia):
Harris Nights 286 No. 48.
”Wait till men come to take me from trap, then eat them.“

Troll lets the first two goats pass on the bridge so that he may eat the
biggest one. He is thrown in the water. Type 123*.
Dwarf persuaded to wait for ram.

Lamb and ewe escape. Ram butts dwarf into river. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Ram promises to jump into wolf‘s belly.

Gives him a hard knock.
The stunned wolf thinks he has swallowed the ram. (Cf. †K579.5.1.) Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 122E*.

Wolf is requested by horse to start eating from the rear;
kicked to death.
”Soak me in the pond so that I will be juicy.“

Trickster, cornered by leopard, leaps into swamp, then says he is too dirty to
eat. Leopard smells of him and agrees. Africa (Wute): Sieber ZsES XII 173.
Cannibals advised to be absent while hero is being cooked;

else he will not taste right. Hero escapes. Africa (Zulu):
Callaway 6.

Cleanest girl to be eaten by ogress: clever girl shakes
sesame into fire to simulate sound of burning lice.

Pursuer persuaded to put oil on a tree when he wants to
climb after fugitives.
Trickster persuades pursuers to play fatal deceptive game.

content: Prisoner released on promise to wed guard (captor).
Prisoner released on promise of life-long allegiance.
Escape by putting captor off guard.
child:
Captive pretends to
louse the captor but deceives him by cracking berries in the teeth (or the
like). India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales
326 n. 174; S. A. Indian (Yuracare): Alexander Lat. Am. 314, Métraux BBAE
CXLIII (3) 502.

Girl pretends to be cooking meal for animal husband:
escapes. India: Thompson-Balys.
Escape from madman by sending him for cooking water.

Escape on ship on wheels after having deceived the captor
into laying away sword and helm to receive pretended gift.

Man in devils’ power makes them believe he will return and
is permitted to leave.

Deceives them.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3303, Legends Nos. 578ff.

content: Animal captor appeased by being fed captive’s family.
Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 9 No. 5, 35 No. 27.
Boy in hole escapes descending log by digging hole.

child: One animal swallows another to save him from pursuer.
Tiger-mother hides concealed guests in jar.

S. A. Indian (Chiriguano):
Métraux RMLP XXXIII 162, (Yuracare): ibid 144.
Confederate sits on hero and saves him.
Rescuer disguised as officer gains custody of prisoner.
Boys scolded in order to conceal their identity.

Icelandic: Hrólfs saga
Kraka 10 ch. 3, Boberg.

Son mentioned as daughter in order to save him from enemy’s
pursuit.
Boys warned by dogs‘ names to escape.
Sons warned by talk to oaks to hide.
Confederate in disguise helps man escape.
Confederate in disguise as beggar helps to escape.
Helper dressed in bear’s skin helps to escape.

Krappe Scandinavian
Studies XVIII (1945) 275--283; Icelandic: Þiðriks saga I 261-72 (cf. 339--40),
Asbjørnsen og Moe No. 58 (type 590), Boberg.

Confederate in disguise as ”troll“ frightens king’s men,
while his daughter helps prisoner to escape.
Confederate saves fugitive by shammed pursuit.
Confederate causes confusion so that prisoner can escape.

Prisoner escapes by means of wolf which he lures near by
smearing honey on the feet.
Escape by cutting fetters on stones, etc.

Confederate persuades captor to throw away disguised
trickster.

content:
Bird’s call attracts attention of pursuer so that trickster
escapes.

Escape by catching hold of limbs of tree while passing
under it.
Birds escape death by flying away with net.

India: Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II
1065.

Escape by announcing great catastrophe (end of world or the
like).

Small animal in mouth of larger causes captor to spit him
out.
Dupe persuaded to throw away his knife.

Later must go hungry because he has no knife to cut the
meat. Africa (Benga): Nassau 86 No. 4, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 381
No. 6, (Kaffir): Theal 106, (Thonga): Junod 220; West Indies: Flowers 535.

Dupe sleeps on the ”king‘s bed“: falls into well beneath
and dies.
Dupe tricked into breaking tabu by lying.
Dupe tricked into sitting on hot iron.

Fox persuades bear to lie in the haycock and wait for
sheep.
He sets fire to the hay. (Cf. †K1013.2.) Cheremis: Sebeok-Nyerges.

Fairy induces hero to dive into lake which makes person
old.
Peas strewn on stairs so that person will slip.

Treacherous counselor persuades king’s son to woo his
father‘s young bride whom he is sent to get, and as he tells the king that he
is her lover both are killed.
child:
God persuades hero to substitute a false bride for his
father;

this results in a fight where the
son kills the father. Icelandic: Boberg.

content:
Brothers duped into killing each other by slander that one
of them is father to the other’s child.
Goddess arouses heroes‘ jealousy and eternal fighting.

Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 123, Herrmann Saxo II 361ff.,
Boberg.

Casual words uttered by dupe used to cheat him of his
property.

A miser is persuaded by his
servant to fast nine days. He calls out on the fifth day ”the half“ and on the
ninth ”the whole“. She makes people believe that he is making his will and
giving everything to her. It is so ordered. Danish: Kristensen Jyske
Folkeminder VII No. 30.

A
father sends his sons one after the other to pasture the goat. The goat always
declares that he has had nothing to eat. The father angrily sends his sons from
home and learns, when he himself tries to pasture the goat, that he has been
deceived. *Type 212; *BP I 346.
Trickster teaches a dupe a strange language.
child: The laborer teaches his master birds’ talk.

Puts him in a sack and beats him. Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 2443*.

Cuts
off tip of pupil‘s tongue or orders him to lick cold iron--pupil injures
himself. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2444*.

content: Dupe digs till he dies of exhaustion.

Rabbit entertains the wolf with his antics until the
rabbit’s wife can change to another hole. The wolf continues to dig. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 31 No. 72A*.
Dupe persuaded to transform self into animal.
Duck persuades cock to cut off his crest and spurs.

The cat attacks the duck, who cries, ”peace, gentlemen,
peace!“ Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 36 No. 208*.
Man dupes animals into turning their tongues upside down.

Taught incriminating song or persuaded to wear
incriminating clothes. Africa (Nigeria): Tremearne FL XXI 489 No. 20; American
Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 69 No. 13, (Virginia): Smiley JAFL XXXII 366;
Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 235; Bahama: Parsons MAFLS XIII 70 No. 33; West
Indies: Flowers 534.
Falsified message brings about a war.

Irish myth: Cross; Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 191;
Icelandic: Herrmann Saxo II 361ff., Boberg.
child:
Men disrobe and report they have been attacked: bring about
war.
Message falsified to bring about death of lovers.

content: Woman induces men to fight over her and kill each other.

Woman makes trouble between man and wife: the hair from his
beard.

She tells the wife to increase her
husband’s
love by cutting a hair from his beard. Also tells the husband that his wife
will try to cut his throat. He kills his wife. *Type 1353; *Wesselski Märchen
194; Chauvin II 158 No. 42, 195 No. 20; *Wesselski Mönchslatein 27 No. 22;
*Prato Zs. f. Vksk. IX 189ff., 311ff.; Herbert III 399; Hilka Neue Beiträge zur
Erzählungslit. d. Mittelalters 19 No. 17; Scala Celi 109b No. 610; Krappe
Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 48; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Woman makes trouble between man and wife (to lick husband‘s
body).

Woman makes trouble between man and wife: to keep certain
rendezvous.

content: Liar brings about fight between dupes.

Irish myth: Cross; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies:
Flowers 535.
child: Trickster tells lies to fishes and causes them to fight.

Jackal tells tales so as to get buffalo and tiger to kill
each other;

feeds on the meat. India:
Thompson-Balys; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 823.
Trickster attempts to bring friends to fight.
(Plans that one kill the other.) Irish myth: *Cross.

Calumniators try to bring friendly kings to fight, but fail
at last.

content: Undesignated present starts quarrel for its possession.

Ogres (large animals, sharp-elbowed women) duped into
fighting each other.

Trickster strikes one so that he thinks the other has done it.
*Type 1640; BP I 148ff.; Köhler-Bolte I 565; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX
20; Greek: Fox 112 (Jason); India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 175 No.
75; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list Nos. 42, 43, 44;
Eskimo (Mackenzie area): Jenness 44; Koryak: Jochelson JE VI 37, 376; N. A.
Indian: *Thompson Tales 327 n. 181; Africa: Weeks Jungle 39ff.
child: Enemies duped into fighting each other.

Missile thrown among enemies causes them to fight one
another.

DeVries Tijdschrift voor
Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLVII 73; Icelandic: Boberg; Greek: Frazer
Apollodorus I 317 n. 1; Indonesia: De Vries’s list No. 286.
Object thrown into air causes enemies to fight over it.

Norse: Hdwb. d. Märchens
I 440a n. 287.

Bird lighting on the heads of group of men causes them to
kill one another with blows on the head.
Blind men duped into fighting: money to be divided.

Trickster says that he
is giving one of them money to be divided with the others. Gives it to none.
They quarrel and fight. (Cf. †K1883.6.) *Wesselski Gonnella 126 No. 21; *Bédier
Fabliaux 447; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1577*; Russian: Andrejev No 1577I*;
Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
”I don’t believe you have a gold coin.“

Trickster handed money by each of four blind beggars, each
thinking that member of group speaks. India: Thompson-Balys.
Blind men duped into fighting: stolen meat.

The trickster steals one piece of meat. The blind accuse
each other and fight. Italian Novella: Rotunda; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales
298 n. 89; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Thomas 82, 124.

Blind men duped into fighting: strings leading to water
removed.

Fb ”snor“; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 298 n. 89.

content: Wolf (lion) approaches too near to horse: kicked in face.

*Type 47B; *BP III 77; *Baum MLN XXXVII 350ff.; Crane
Vitry 147f. No. 33, 197 No. 152.
child:
Wolf (lion) as sham doctor looks at horse‘s foot: kicked in
face.

*Baum MLN XXXVII 350; Herbert III 13; *Crane Vitry 197 No. 152; Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. IX 87; *Wesselski Märchen 250 No. 58; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Sow kicks wolf into stream when he comes close to baptize
her pigs.

Thus she saves them from him.
Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Dupe tries to dig up alleged treasure buried in ant hill:
bitten by snake and killed.
Dissension aroused in army by casting suspicion on general.

A general destroys everything except what belongs to the
general of the enemy. Thus he brings about suspicion that the two leaders are
in league. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 539.

Hare flatters other animals into letting it bite off their
ears.
Pepper given as ointment for burns.

(Cf. †K1045.) Japanese:
Ikeda; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 69ff. No. 9.

child: Biting on stone given as remedy for toothache.

Leopard wants teeth filed: large stone dropped from tree
knocks all leopard‘s teeth out.

content:
Beetles and barley introduced into wounds on pretence of
healing them.
Feeling pulse: doctor severs arteries instead.

Under
pretence of curing eyesight the trickster blinds the dupe. (Often with a
glowing mass thrust into the eye.) *Type 1135; *BP III 375; **Hackman
Polyphemsage; *Herbert III 40ff.; Hervieux IV 204 No. 29; Icelandic: Boberg;
Spanish Exempla: Keller; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden
140.
child: Fool deceived into curing headache by removing his eyes.
Ashes as remedy for sore eyes.

content:
The trickster pretends to make the dupe
beautiful. Injures him. *Cosquin Études 385ff.; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Chinese: Graham; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list
Nos. 73, 74; Eskimo (Bering Strait): Nelson RBAE XVIII 467; N. A. Indian:
*Thompson Tales 352 n. 271, (California): Gayton and Newman 83; Africa (Ekoi):
Talbot 387, (Kaffir): Theal 99, (Wute): Sieber ZsES XII 69f., 172.
child: Making the beard golden: ”such a one“.

A man named ”Such a one“ persuades an ogre to have his
beard gilded. He covers it with tar and leaves the ogre caught to the
tar-kettle. The ogre with his tar-kettle wanders about and asks everyone, ”Have
you seen such a one?“ *Type 1138.

The fox persuades the
wolf to lie on the hay in order to be painted. He sets fire to it. *Type 8; *Dh
IV 239; *Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 67ff.; American Negro: Harris
Friends 60 ff. No. 8.
Making wife beautiful by burning her.

S. A. Indian
(Chiriguano): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 175; Africa (Cameroon): Rosenhuber 79.

Burning children on promise of giving them fawn’s beautiful
spots.
Trickster to give wings to tiger.

Trick: breaking legs for prowess in dancing (or for
swiftness).

content:
Dupe injures self on fence of thorns surrounding
food-plants.
Dupe made to sit on hot stone.
child: Jackal persuaded to come to fireplace for food.

content: Hot porridge in the ogre‘s throat.
He is tricked into burning his throat. *Type 1131.

Trickster pretends to give dupe magic power to produce
food.
child:
Dupe told he can get meat by putting hand up animal‘s anus:
animal drags him.

Jackal puts head in anus of sham-dead camel: caught and
punished.

content: Dupe persuaded to climb rope for food: rope breaks.

Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 7 No. 3, 9 No. 4, (Kaffir):
Theal 190; American Negro: Harris Nights 45.
Stone (hard fruit) thrown into greedy dupe’s mouth.

India: Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Anesaki 330; Africa
(Hottentot): Bleek 10 No. 4, (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith and Dale II 387 No. 13.

The fox persuades the wolf to do so. *Type
21; Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 85; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: The fox suggests eating his own brains.

The wolf, wanting to get brains, strikes his head against
a tree. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *21A.
Tiger persuaded to eat own eyes.

content:
Animals are to eat one
another up to avoid starvation. The fox persuades them to start with the
smallest. *Type 20; *Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 81ff.
Dupe imitates trickster’s thefts and is caught.

*Types 1 (and notes to
†K371.1.), 66**; Japanese: Ikeda; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Basden 274.

The
bear is persuaded to fish with his tail through a hole in the ice. When he is
attacked and tries to escape, he loses his tail. *Type 2; *BP II 111; *Dh IV
219; Krohn Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI) 26ff.; *Fb ”ræv“ III 113b, ”bjørn“ IV 43a, ”ulv“ III
971a.--Lappish: Qvigstad Lappiske Eventyr II 3, III 3; Japanese: Ikeda; Korean:
Zong in-Sob 159 No. 69; Eskimo (Mackenzie Area): Jenness 44; N. A. Indian:
Thompson CColl II 438; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 120 No. 25,
Nights 113 No. 21, (Pennsylvania): Parsons JAFL XXX 214, (Virginia): Smiley
JAFL XXXII 361, (South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXIV 12.
child:
Dupe bound fast and then attacked. Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 199--201, 204;
India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list Nos. 35, 88; N. A. Indian
(Hupa): Goddard U Cal I 154ff., Kroeber JAFL XXI 224; Africa (Zulu): Callaway
6, 358, (Kaffir): Theal 110, 183, (Basuto): Jacottet 20 No. 2, (Ila, Rhodesia):
Smith and Dale II 385f., (Hottentot): Bleek I No. 1, (Thonga): Junod 217;
American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 339 No. 59; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS
XVII *241 No. 14, 233f.; West Indies: Flowers 533.

Hair tied to basket so that dupe kills self when she throws
basket down.
Basket tied to wolf‘s tail and filled with stones.

Wolf is persuaded that it is filled with fish. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 28 No. 2, Espinosa III Nos. 199--204, 209, 211, 223, Espinosa Jr.
Nos. 3. 4.
Bear persuaded to slide down rock.

Wears off tail. American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights
113 No. 21.

content:
The dupe is stung. Type 49; Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
1637*; Mexican: Espinosa JAFL XXIV 419ff.; Chinese: Graham; Indonesia:
Coster-Wijsman 38 No. 26; N. A. Indian (Menomini): Skinner JAFL XXVI 75; Africa
(Basuto): Jacottet 44ff.; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 51 No. 10, 83
No. 16, Remus 135 No. 28, (Virginia): Parsons JAFL XXXV 274.
child: Dupe allowed to guard ”king’s drum“: it is a wasp nest.

India: *Thompson-Balys; Java: Dixon 188 n. 5; cf.
DeVries‘s list No. 12.

Dupe allowed to guard ”king‘s girdle“: it is a snake, which
bites him.
Dupe persuaded to pick up biting ants.
Dupe persuaded to sit on ant hole.

Animal made to believe sound of swarming bees is that of
her children singing in school.

Rushes to
water to relieve stings and is drowned. Africa (Suto): Jacottet I 36ff. No. 5.
Dupe induced to strike at bee‘s nest: badly bitten.

content: Dupe persuaded to steal food: cannot escape.
child:
Cannot escape through the entrance hole. *Type 41; *BP II
109, IV 318; *Dh IV 232; *Chauvin III 45; Wienert FFC LVI 60 (ET 226); Halm
Aesop No. 31; *Graf FFC XXXVIII 71ff.; Herbert III 374 No. 11; Fb ”ulv“ III
971a.--Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 21; N. A. Indian:
Thompson CColl II 438; Africa: Frobenius Atlantis XII 291, 327, (Wachaga):
Gutmann 188.

Jackal eating into elephant’s dead body becomes a prisoner
when it dries up;

is released when storm
moistens hide. Buddhist myth: Malalasekera II 1131.

The fox ties one end of the rope around the wolf’s neck, the other to
the cow they intend to eat. The cow drags the wolf to the house where the man
skins it. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 29 No. 47C*, Espinosa III No. 208.

Water-monster, trying to pull horse into water, is dragged
to house where he begs for his life and is spared.

Bear throws hens to the fox, falls from the roof-beam, and
is beaten.
Wolf brings cake from the window-sill.

He imitates the fox in so doing, but rings a bell, so that
he is beaten. Type 160***.
Turtle induced to rob in a man‘s garden.
Fox eats cake: gets brass pot caught on neck.

Thieving wolf persuaded to stick head through handle of jar
of wine so as to be able to carry it off and also sing.

content: Rat leaves serpent behind, through spared to rescue him.

The two are imprisoned
together in a sevenfold cloth covering. The serpent refrains from eating the
rat so that the latter can gnaw the cloth for them. The rat gnaws his own way
out and leaves the serpent. Köhler-Bolte I 535.
Tiger persuaded to cross river carrying vat rim-upwards.

Trickster fills it with stones and tiger loses it. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Hot tin under the horse‘s tail.

The smith promises to make the horse wild. The numskull on
the horse’s back. *Type 1142; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 224 No. 64.
Penzer V 1f. 3 n. 1; Siberian: Holmberg Siberian 363.
Plot to induce king to commit a crime.
His line thus will forfeit succession. Irish myth: Cross.

Animals hidden in various parts of a house attack owner
with their characteristic powers and kill him when he enters.

*Types 130, 210; **Aarne
FFC XI; *BP I 75, 135; *Hoebel JAFL LIV 1ff.; Missouri French: Carrière; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda, Anesaki 331; Korean: Zong in-Sob 160 No. 70;
Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 99.
Man persuaded to go to store with scythe.
Is tied up as madman. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Dupe persuaded that sheep have been lost in river. *Type 1535;
*BP II 1ff.; *Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 51; Köhler-Bolte I 91, 190; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob 105 No. 56; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 26
No. 5.
child: Dupe induced to dive for alleged jewels.

Type 1535; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa (Vai):
Klingenheben ZsES XVI 102ff. No. 8, (Madagascar): Renel II 89ff. No. 83.

content: Dragon attacks own image in mirror.
Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 40 No. 300; Japanese: Ikeda.
Robber persuaded to climb down moonbeam.

A man hearing a robber
enter tells his wife aloud that he always makes a prayer and then enters the
house by climbing down a moonbeam. The thief tries it and falls. *Chauvin II
84, IX 31 No. 22; *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 231 No. 81; *Pauli (ed. Bolte)
No. 628; Günter 104 and note 226; Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 21; Bødker
Exempler 274 No. 10; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Dupe persuaded to get into grass in order to learn new
dance.

Grass set on fire. Korean: Zong
in-Sob 158f. No. 69; Africa (Ibo, Nigeria): Thomas 94.
child: Crocodile hides in strawstack and is burned to death.

content: Dupe allowed to guard ”king‘s litter“: sticks in mud.

The trickster gives the ogre the gun to smoke. *Type 1157; *Fb ”tobak“ III
814a.
Deer persuaded to butt head into tree.

Kills himself. N. A. Indian (Catawba): Speck JAFL XXVI 324
No. 2.
child:
Serpent‘s jewel is covered with spiked helmet so that when
he tries to recover it he strikes and is spiked to death.

content: Dupe puts hand (paws) into cleft of tree (wedge, vise).

*Type 38; *BP I 68, II 99 n. 1; Chauvin II 86 No. 20, III
77; Dh IV 231ff.; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 18, 250; India: Thompson-Balys;
Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 64; New Britain: Dixon 195 n. 30; N. A. Indian
(Tepoztlan): Boas JAFL XXV 247 No. 2; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights
33 No. 7.
child:
Dupe wishing to learn to play fiddle has finger caught in
cleft of tree.

Dupe wishing to learn to play flute puts tongue in split
bamboo.
Dupe caught in crack in ground.
Ogre helps tortoise who snaps jaws to and catches him.

content:
A man is induced to get into a tree which magically shoots
upward. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 332 n. 199, (California): Gayton and
Newman 70, 78; Africa (Jaunde): Nekes 236, (Benga): Nassau 176 No. 23.
child: Dupe persuaded to climb tall tree.
Falls. American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 357 No. 63.

content:
Hero
bends tree over but when he catches breath the tree shoots him to the sky.
*Type 1051; BP III 333.
child:
Tree becomes light (after all honey has been collected from
nests), springs back and kills tribe‘s enemies.

content:
The trickster takes an oath by touching
iron (a trap). The dupe imitates but hits the iron so hard that he gets caught.
*Type 44; *Köhler-Bolte I 408f.
child:
Animal gets bait from trap by luring another animal into
it.

content:
The bear eats a horse which has a bell tied around its neck. The fox rings the
bell and gets blamed. Type 40*; Russian: Andrejev No. 40.
Ogre induced to sit on reversed harrow.

Dupe induced to sit on sharp stones (concealed as soft
seat).
Dupe deceived concerning the thunder; finally killed by it.

The dupe has asked the trickster to tell him when it
thunders. *Type 1148A; Estonian, Finnish, Swedish, Latvian, Lithuanian: *Balys
Tautosakos Darbai VI 13--26. Cf. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 327 n. 179.

Minister dupes raja into entering body of dead parrot, then
enters rajah‘s body.
Falling beam in cave kills travelers lured within.
Dupe tricked in race into falling into a pit.

Sheep makes fox believe that the hunter is a priest, the
dog his servant, etc.
Dupe induced to eat sharp (stinging, bitter) fruit.

India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 13;
Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 376.
child: Monkey ”shares“ ointment with tiger: produces sores.

Korean: Zong in-Sob 158 No. 69; Africa (Cameroon): Meinhof
77.

content: Water bird takes dupe to sea: shakes him off into water.

*Type 226; *Fb ”and“ IV 12b; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No.
69, Dixon 193 *n. 20.
child:
Elephant offers to let chameleon hold on to his tail: it is
oiled and chameleon falls off.

content:
Dupe lets himself be carried aloft by bird and dropped. *Type 225; *Parsons
JAFL XXXI 218 n. 1; *Fb ”ræv“ III 114a; Herbert III 37ff.;
*Dh IV 269; Wienert FFC LVI *46 (ET 51), 50 (ET 98), 93 (ST 63), *123 (ST 320);
Halm Aesop No. 419; Gaster Oldest Stories 82.--Spanish: Espinosa III Nos.
218--220, Espinosa Jr. Nos. 21--23; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia:
DeVries’s list Nos. 70, 108; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 294 n. 80, Thompson
CColl II 449, (Klikitat): Jacobs U Wash II 30; Africa (Ila, Rhodesia): Smith
and Dale II 373 No. 23; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Remus 103 No. 21,
(Virginia): Bacon and Parsons JAFL XXXV 263.
child: Flight by putting on bird feathers.

Dupe falls. Spanish Exempla: Keller; India:
Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 295 n. 80.

content: The bear bites the seemingly dead horse‘s tail.

Is dragged off by the
horse. *Type 47A; *BP III 75; Dh IV 235; Krohn Bär (Wolf) und Fuchs (JSFO VI)
70; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 163--7, 172--4; Korean: Zong in-Sob 105 No. 56;
N. A. Indian (Chickasaw): Speck JAFL XXVI 292; American Negro (Georgia): Harris
Nights 8 No. 2, 208 No. 36.

Dupe persuaded to scald self with hot water in order to
learn languages.

child: Dupe persuaded to rub salt on wounds.

content:
Irish myth: Cross; Italian Novella: Rotunda; Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 15; Marquesas: Handy 110; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 442; West
Indies: Flowers 533.
A beggar tells the bishop how to stay warm.

For a gulden he tells him that he should wear all his
clothes when he goes horseback in winter. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 513.

Dupe persuaded to pay for learning this dance (really
moving toward and away from a fire). India: Thompson-Balys.
Thief masked as devil bought off by frightened owner.

Type 1525; Scotch: Campbell-McKay No. 11; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 3442, Legends Nos. 859f.

child:
Deceptive bargain: as much gold in reward as sticks to
poet’s hair when poured over him: he smears it with tar.

content: Cheater is forced to eat excrements.

Gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the
peasant‘s jade, provided the peasant will eat its excrements. The peasant finds
no difficulty in the task, whereas the gentleman, put to the same condition
when he wants to get back his horse, finds it impossible. Lithuanian: Balys
Index No. 1533*; Russian: Andrejev No. 1529 I*; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 324f.
No. 48, FFC CXXVIII 271f. No. 170.

child:
Man collects toll fraudulently, stamps “Brass Gate” on
receipts he gives.

People think this is
some Government phrase. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: A ribbon long enough to reach from ear to ear.

The rascal has had an ear cut off and this is in a distant
city. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 713.
Bargain: if the sun reverses its course.

Because of an eclipse the sun is held to have done so, and
Atreus becomes king. Greek: Fox 120.

Until the log burns out: time given servant for Christmas
holidays.

Soaks the log so that it burns a
week. North Carolina: Brown Collection I 702.

child:
Man sells three hundred foxes to buyer who agrees to “take
them as they run”: reds, silvers, crosses. He gets a large payment to bind the
bargain, waves his hand at the woods: “I sold them as they run; and they‘re
running.” Canada: Baughman.

Man
boasts of hog so big that a man could not reach its back if he holds his hand
as high as possible. A stranger buys the hog, sight-unseen. The seller takes
him to the hog, shows the buyer that the hog’s back is much below his hand when
he holds it as high as possible. England: Baughman.

Trickster lends bamboo on condition that it is returned
exactly as it is.

content:
As hostages the dogs are handed over to the wolves; the
young wolves to the sheep. The wolves then attack and kill the sheep. Ward II
320; *Herbert III 168f. No. 22; *Crane Vitry 152 No. 45; Wienert FFC LVI *50
(ET 96), 97 (ST 108); Halm Aesop No. 268; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 47.
Deceptive bargain based on an unusual name.
child:
This is the name of an estate, which the king unwittingly
gives away. Anderson FFC XLII 360; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *925.

content: The man helps the horse against the stag.

The horse must agree to be saddled and bridled. The man
then refuses to release him. Wienert FFC LVI *71 (ET 356), 108 (ST 208); Halm
Aesop No. 175; Herbert III 9; Crane Vitry 182 No. 110; Jacobs Aesop 208 No. 33.
Dupe denied food until hands are clean.

Grass burned around food makes continued washings
unavailing. Africa (Zezuru): Posselt Fables of the Veld (London, 1929) 110
(Northern Rhodesia): Worthington The Little Wise One (London, 1930) 25ff.,
(Nyanja): Rattray Some Folk-Lore Stories ... in Chinyanja (London, 1907) 145f.
No. 22, (Namwanga): Dewar Chinamwanga Stories (Livingstonia, 1900) 47, (Fang):
Anthropos XXVIII 292 No. 7, (Bulu): Krug JAFL XXV 114, (Mossi, Nioniossee,
Samo, Yarse, Silmi-Mossi, Fulah): Tauxier Le Noir du Yatenga (Paris, 1917)
458f. No. 59.
Stolen property sold to its owner.
child:
Trickster steals farmer’s cow and then sells her to the
farmer.

Merchant buys the same article several times from the same
or different seller.

content:
Hole
in the hat and hat over a pit. *Type 1130; *BP III 421; Lithuanian: Balys
Legends No. 752.

The ogre and the trickster agree to fell a large tree. The
trickster purposely dulls his axe on a stone and then asks the ogre to
exchange. Rather than work with a dull axe, the ogre does all the work. *Type
1050.

The servant girl eats secretly; the miser starves. Danish:
Kristensen Jyske Folkeminder VII No. 30; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1568A*.
Deceptive bargain: first to say “Good morning.”

The first to give the greeting shall have the disputed
property. The trickster is early on the scene and witnesses the other’s
adultery. He may keep the property without saying good morning. *Type 1735;
*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 324.
child:
First to greet the other in morning will lose beauty
contest.
Dispute is to be settled thus. (Cf. †H1529.) India: Thompson-Balys.

content:
The ogre is to fulfill three wishes of the peasant. The
latter wishes for all the tobacco and brandy in the world and then some more
brandy in addition. The devil must admit failure. Type 1173*.
Deceptive bargain: a sack of corn as reward.

Trickster has an enormous sack made. *Wesselski Gonnella
131 No. 25.
child: Deceptive bargain: as much grain as will go in a rope.

Trickster encloses whole crop. Scotch: Campbell-McKay No.
30.

content: Deceptive bargain: as much bread as he wants to eat.

The baker fixes his price at the rate for twenty loaves.
The trickster eats thirty. *Chauvin II 125 No. 124.

The
trickster makes a bargain with his master that the first to become angry must
submit to punishment. He thereupon heaps abuses on his master till the latter
breaks out in anger and must take his punishment. *Types 650A, 1000; *BP II
293; *Fb “næse” II 716a, “vred” III 1195b; Köhler-Bolte I 327; Irish myth: *Cross, Breton:
Sébillot Incidents s.v. “domestique”; Missouri French:
Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 240; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 433f.;
Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 113.
child: Anger bargain: may God give you a penny.

A servant and his mistress agree that when they are angry
with each other they shall say, “May God give you a penny!” When the master
says this, the servant says, “May he give you two!” They keep increasing the
amount till those who hear wonder at the performance. The mistress tells them,
“You don’t know the coin.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) Nos. 365, 813.
Giant cheated in division of spoils of the chase.

Jackal cheats other animals of elephant they have killed
together.

Deceptive crop division: above the ground, below the
ground.

Of root crops the ogre (stupid animal) chooses the tops; of other crops the
roots. (Cf. †J242.8.) *Type 1030; *BP III 355, 363 n. 1; **J. Hackman “Sagan om skördelningen”
Folkloristika och etnografiska studier III 140ff.; *Krohn “Bar (Wolf) und
Fuchs” JSFO
VI 104ff.; Wünsche Teufel 70ff.; Taylor PMLA XXXVI 58 n. 34; *Köhler-Bolte I
69; **Hdwb. d. Märchens I 193a, 593b; *Fb “rød”.--Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 441, (1928) 271; Swiss:
Jegerlehner Oberwallis 324 No. 161; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish Exempla:
Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; Japanese: Ikeda; West Indies: Flowers 497; N. A.
Indian: Thompson CColl II 441, 447ff.; American Negro: Parsons JAFL XXX 175.
Deceptive grain division: the corn and the chaff.

The bear chooses the chaff because of its greater bulk. At
the mill the fox‘s grain makes a different sound from the bear’s. *Type 9B; *Dh
IV 249ff.; *Krohn “Bar (Wolf) und Fuchs” JSFO VI 97ff.; Hdwb. d. Märchens I 193b.
Deceptive nut and olive division: inside and outside.

The clever man chooses the kernel of the nuts and the
outside of the olive. BP III 363.
Deceptive sacrifice of nuts and dates.

Trickster sacrifices only the shells of the nuts and the
inside of the dates. Wienert FFC LVI 80 (ET 456), 103 (ST 164); Halm Aesop No.
315.
Deceptive division of pigs: curly and straight tails.

All with curly tails belong to the trickster, others to
the dupe. *Type 1036.
Deceptive division of animals for shearing.

The trickster shears the sheep; the dupe the pig. *Type
1037.
In dividing the fish, the dupe gets the bones.

Evil takes lower half of wife, Good takes upper half.
Child begotten by Evil not permitted to nurse the top half which belongs to
Good. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

The common cow and bull: one gets front of cow and back of
bull.

Evil chooses lambs, leaving milk to Good. Lambs drink up
all milk. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

Barber’s and jackal‘s common garden: jackal pretends that
garden has not yielded any fruit at all.
Monkey cheats fox of his share of bananas.

Climbs on a tree and tosses peelings down upon fox. India:
Thompson-Balys.
Deceptive partnership between man and ogre.
The eaten grain and the cock as damages.

A trickster has only a grain of corn; this is eaten by a
cock, which he demands and receives as damages. Likewise when a hog eats the cock
and the ox eats the hog. *Type 1655; *BP II 201; *DeVries Volksverhalen II 381
No. 145; India: Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Friends 176
No. 24; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII *262 No. 63.

Trickster demands return of food guest has just eaten: gets
damages.
Damages claimed for loss of a charm.

Princess lets trickster’s fly (alleged to be a charm)
escape. India: Thompson-Balys.

Horse concealed by owner in loft of stable at inn. Pierre
Faifeu No. 46.

Damages for accidentally broken water pot: to pay for
elephant.
Payment to lame man who claims that man‘s father lamed him.
Deceptive wages: as much rice as will go on a leaf.
Deceptive wages: two grains and land to plant them on.

Grain multiplies and takes up all of dupe‘s land. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content: Profitable league made with both parties to a quarrel.
Deceptive bargain: an ox for five pennies.

A woman who has been left the ox on condition that she
give the proceeds to the poor offers it for five pennies, but it must be bought
along with a cock at twelve florins. She gives the five pennies to the poor and
keeps the twelve florins. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 462; *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin II 188 No. 370; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *2449.
child: Small niche in house brings large price.

House sold reserving niche. This becomes such a nuisance
that buyer pays heavily for it. India: Thompson-Balys.

content: Deceptive bargain: the ogre and the copper coins.

Every time the copper coin is paid out, the ogre must make
a new one. The man buys an extensive property and pays with a large number of
copper coins. He threatens to buy another and the ogre goes back on his
contract. Type 1182*.
Deceptive bargain: a peck of grain for each stack.

The man who is to receive this share of the crop makes
very small stacks. *Type 1155.
Deceptive bargain with ogre: buying trees.
Trees to be neither straight nor crooked. *Type 1048.

child: Dog as wolf’s shoemaker eats up the materials.
Devours the cow, hog, etc. furnished him. Type 102.

content:
Trickster persuades dupe to sacrifice animal and give it to
him as payment for supposed services.

A man promises in confession to steal only a small amount.
He steals a rope with a mare on the end of it. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 146 No.
1800A; West Indies: Flowers 498.

child: Charging thirty cakes for cooking twenty-five.

Crab demands seven patas as payment for four patas of paddy
frog has borrowed.

Crow demands young swan in payment for helping swan find
feed for its young.
Camel has offered one pound of flesh to jackal for help.

content:
Wealth (or woman) is on platform. First thing touched is
ladder leading up. India: *Thompson-Balys.

The boy promises the soldier what the king has promised to give
him. The soldier receives a beating in place of the boy. *Type 1610; **Reinhard
JAFL XXXVI 380; *BP I 62; *Basset 1001 Contes I 321; Köhler-Bolte I 495;
*Chauvin V 282 No. 166; *Wesselski Märchen 202 No. 13; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
614; Hibbard 80 n. 3; Wesselski Mönchslatein 161 No. 122.--English: Wells 161
(Sir Cleges); Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.

child:
As much land bought as can be surrounded by an ox-hide.
The hide is cut into very small strips. *Type 2400; *Basset Revue d‘ethnographie et des trad.
pop. IV 97; Köhler-Bolte II 319ff.; Katanoff “Türkische Sagen über
Besitznahme v. Ländern nach Art der Dido”
Keleti Szemle III (1902) 173ff.; *Fb “ride” III 52b; Basset RTP VI 335, *VII 549, VIII
409; Rosières RTP VI 52; Sébillot RTP V 186; Cordier RTP II 295,
354.--Icelandic: Gering Islendsk Æventyri (Halle, 1883) II 92ff., Herrmann Saxo
II 656, Boberg; French: Sébillot France IV 111, 180, 214; Estonian: Loorits,
Some Notes on the Repertoire of the Estonian Folk-Tale, Tartu 1937, 23ff.;
Greek: Aly Volksmärchen bei Herodot 114, 117; Egyptian: Legrain Louqsor sans
les Pharaons (Paris, 1914) 64; N. A. Indian (Wyandot): Barbeau GSCan XI 271 No.
91.

Deceptive land purchase: as much land as Vishnu can lie
upon (or can step over in three steps).
His worshippers claim for him the whole earth. Hindu: Keith 79.

Deceptive land purchase: boundary fixed by flight of a
goose.

Subject given as much land as a
goose can fly over without lighting. The man carries the goose with its wings
extended over an enormous territory. Harou RTP XXIII 169.

Deceptive land purchase: as much land as a shawl will
cover.

An immense shawl prepared. Harou
RTP XXIII 169; Java: Bezemer Fabelen en Legenden 216ff.

Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be covered by
saint‘s hood.

Only by snatching up hood
does seller prevent it from covering whole territory. Irish myth: Cross.

Land grant: as much land as can be covered by saint’s
mantle.
Deceptive land purchase: bounds fixed by a race.
One man has supernatural speed. RTP XXI 166.

Deceptive land purchase: bounds fixed by throwing object
(axe, spear).

Thrower has extraordinary
strength. RTP XVIII 222; Harou RTP XI 524.

Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be surrounded
in a certain time.
Land bargain: land surrounded by a horse (cow) in one day.

Fb “ride” III 52b; Harou RTP XIV 90; India:
Thompson-Balys.
Land bargain: land ridden around during a sermon.

bribes charioteer to turn
back whenever chieftain faints from loss of blood. Irish myth: Cross.

Land purchase: as much as can be plowed (fenced) in a
certain time.

*Fb “plove” II 850a, “ride” III 52b; cf. Olrik
Danske Studier (1910) 4ff.; Icelandic: Hdwb. d. Märchens I 446b nn. 450--454,
Mac Culloch Eddic 181, Boberg; Frisian: Lübbing Friesische Sagen 95.

Deceptive land purchase: fields that crackle when burnt are
to be his.

He puts bamboo on the fields
before they are burnt so that they crackle. Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 289.

Deceptive land purchase: as much land as can be shadowed by
a tree.

Bought just before sunset.
Japanese: Ikeda; Indonesia: L. de Backer L’Archipel Indien (Paris, 1874) 334.
Deceptive land purchase: enough to raise certain plant.

This is a rapidly
spreading weed which overruns the country. Indonesia: Snouck Hurgronje De
Atjèhers (Leiden, 1893) II 84.

Deceptive land purchase: saint‘s enemy promised as much
land as he can see from certain point.
Saint causes cloud to obstruct vision. Irish myth: Cross.
Land grant: as much land as can be seen on a clear day.

Land grant: as much land as can be seen from certain
eminence.

Deceptive land bargain: saints agree that the one who casts
his staff far enough to reach distant island shall be owner of land.

Staff of one contestant transformed to spear (or dart) and
so alone reaches island. When saint touches weapon, it becomes staff again.
Irish myth: Cross.
Land grant: as far as ox can be heard.

content:
Devil to release man for performing seemingly impossible
task.
The task is performed by trickery.
child: The evil woman in the glass case as the last commodity.

The man is to belong to the devil as soon as he has sold
his goods. If he has any goods that no one will buy, he is to be free. The man
puts an evil old woman in a glass case. When the devil sees her, he recognizes
her. “Whoever knows her will refuse to buy her.” The man goes free. *Type 1170.
Bringing the devil an unknown animal.

The man sends his naked wife on all fours in tar and
feathers. The devil has never seen such an animal. *Type 1091; *BP I 411, III
358; *Fb “pige” II 816a, “kjende” II 140, “tjære” III
811a; Lithuanian: Balys Legends Nos. 755f.
Guessing name of devil‘s secret plant.

The man’s wife in tar and feathers overhears the devil
tell the secret name of the crop he has discovered (tobacco). The devil says to
the supposed animal, “Get out of my tobacco!” Dh I 194; *BP I 411, III 358.
Not to sleep for three successive nights.

The sleepy man: “I am just thinking, that on earth there
are more crooked trees than straight ones ... more hills than plains ... more
water than land ...” The devil goes to ascertain these things, meanwhile the
man sleeps. Unsuccessful imitation by another man. Lithuanian: Balys Index. No.
813*.

content: Devil gets another soul instead of one bargained for.

The devil bargains with a man for his soul, but the man
fulfills his contract and escapes. In envy two persons commit suicide. The
devil rejoices that though he lost one he has gained two. *Types 361, 362*;
Russian: Andrejev No. 362.
Devil’s magic power turned on himself.

The hero who is riding the devil as a horse receives
supernatural strength from plucking a hair from the devil‘s mane. He then spurs
the devil until he agrees to forego his bargain for the man’s soul. Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 67 No. 508A*.

The man has promised himself to the devil in return for
money. He stuffs his clothes with straw and hangs them up. The devil thinks the
man has hanged himself and is satisfied. Type 1190*.

*Type 1145--1154; Irish: Beal XXI 311, O’Suilleabhain 33;
India: Thompson-Balys.
child:
Man whispers in devil‘s ear that his wife is approaching
with her broom again.

content: Devil pounded in knapsack until he releases man.
Devil cheated by imposing an impossible task.
child:
Devil is cheated by giving him task: counting the letters
in the church Bible.

He is unable to read
the holy words. England: Baughman.

content: Devil cheated by religious or magic means.
child:
Devil cheated by having priest draw a sacred circle about
the intended victim.

Type 810; Irish: Beal
XXI 309, O‘Suilleabhain 30; Scotland: Baughman.

Devil cheated of his victim by boy having a bible under his
arm.
Devil cheated when his victim becomes a priest.

*Type 811*; Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 423; Russian:
Andrejev No. 811.

Devil cheated of promised soul by intervention of Virgin
Mary.
The picture of the Virgin Mary saves the priest.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3268, Legends No. 410ff.
Penance of priest saves him from devil.

The priest, who sold his soul to the devil, orders his
servant to cut him (alive) up into pieces, to crucify him on a tree (and the
like), thus saves his soul from the devils. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3267,
Legends Nos. 405--409.

Devil is unable to take man contracted to him when friends
pray over the corpse.

content: Other ways of cheating the devil of his promised soul.
child:
Devil cheated of his promised soul by making the intended
victim drunk.

The devil may punish the
drunk man’s body but has no power over his soul. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 522.

Devil cheated of his promised soul when the victim sells
his to a comrade.

The latter says, “The
devil can take only one soul from each person. I bought the soul so that when
he comes I can give him one and still save my own.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 279.
God cheats the devil of his promised soul.

The devil is to fill a cask full of money. God knocks the
bottom out of the cask. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 91 No. 773B.

Devil is to get soul of man whether he is buried “inside or
outside of church, above or below ground.”

The man has himself buried in the wall of
the church, partly in and partly out of the ground. (Cf. †H1052.) England:
*Baughman.
Man cheats devil by giving him sole instead of soul.
Devil gets an animal in place of a human being.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3285, Legends Nos. 472, 489.
Devil gets a flea instead of man‘s soul.
Creditor to wait till debtor is shaved.

The debtor refuses to finish shaving. Wesselski Bebel I
227 No. 132.

Man who owes 1000 ducats has his creditor arrested for
owing him ten.

Thus he hopes to postpone
payment of his own debt. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content:
Refusal to tell about the Rhine treasure, though condition
demanded is fulfilled when the only one who knows where it is is killed.

Trickster summons all creditors at once, precipitates
fight, and escapes payment.
child:
King promises valuable dog to each of two powerful and
mutually hostile tribes.

At feast prepared
by king the two tribes get into fight and king escapes. Irish myth: *Cross.
Fox is promised chickens: is driven off by dogs.

Husband promises a cow to tiger; wife frightens the tiger
away.
Thor is to give his hammer in return for Freyja as wife.

He masks as a woman and kills the giant who is to receive
the hammer. *DeVries Tijdschrift voor Nederlandsche Taal- en Letterkunde XLVII
293ff.; Icelandic: Boberg.

Man cheats devil of reward: to have man if he gets him at
first grasp.

Man holds cat which flies in
devil‘s
face. (Cf. †K210.) French: Sébillot France IV 182.
Conquered warrior kills victor instead of paying.
Forty-nine are moulded out of earth. Greek: Frazer Apollodorus II 179 n. 3.
After payment, snow takes proper form. Irish myth: *Cross.
Saint ransoms prince for much gold and silver.

Later all the money vanishes. Saint replies that since the
money had been created from nothing, it had simply to return to that state.
*Loomis White Magic 127.

Man to be released when earth is placed at his head
(buried). Dies in grave. Irish myth: Cross.

content:
Trickster disguises himself and escapes notice of
creditors.
Debtor refuses to pay his debt.
child: Refusal to perform part in mutual agreement.
Mutual agreement to sacrifice family members in famine.

Trickster refuses to carry out his part of the bargain.
Louisiana Creole: Fortier MAFLS II 109; India: *Thompson-Balys; Africa: Meinhof
200, (Ekoi): Talbot 337, (Nigeria): Tremaine FL XXI 492, (Vandau): Curtis Songs
and Tales from the Dark Continent (New York, 1920) 44; American Negro
(Georgia): Harris Nights 230ff. Nos. 39, 40, 41; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII
241 No. 14; Cape Verde Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 109 n. 2; West Indies:
Flowers 499ff.

Trickster eats other‘s food and then refuses to divide his
own. Christiansen FFC XXIV 46; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers
501.
The dog refuses to help the wolf.

A farmer plans to kill a faithful old dog. The wolf makes
a plan to save the dog. The latter is to rescue the farmer’s child from the
wolf. The plan succeeds and the dog is rewarded. The wolf in return wants to
steal the farmer‘s sheep. The dog refuses his assistance. *Type 101; Japanese:
Ikeda.
Reward for accomplishment of task deceptively withheld.

Irish myth: Cross; Greek: Fox 81, 94 (Herakles); India:
Thompson-Balys; Tuamotu: Stimson MS (z-G. 13/420).

Dancers given one coin instead of ten and have this taken
away.

Interpreter says they are
complaining that the coin is bad. India: Thompson-Balys.
Refusal to make sacrifice after need is past.

In distress a person promises a sacrifice to a god (saint)
but disregards the promise when the danger passes. Wienert FFC LVI 78f. (ET
438, 448), 139 (ST 442); Halm Aesop Nos. 49, 58; *Crane Vitry 177 No. 102;
Herbert III 8, 36; Scala Celi 56b. No. 316; Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 305; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; India: *Thompson-Balys; West Indies: Flowers 501.
Sailor offers saint a candle as large as a mast.

But he knows that after the storm he will not try to find
such a candle. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 304; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
The sacrifice of the cock is at last carried out.

Postponed until a hawk carries off the cock. Then the
woman says, “O holy St. Martin, I have long owed you a living sacrifice. Take
the cock as sacrifice, and may it be pleasing to you.” Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
320.
Horse withheld as sacrifice to a saint refuses to move.

The deceiver takes the horse to the church planning to
remove him again, but the horse will not stir until a money equivalent has been
paid. Wesselski Bebel II 157 No. 179.
Sick man offers deity 100 bulls for recovery.

When reminded that he does not own so many bulls he
explains that he doesn’t expect the deity to come to enforce payment. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.

Payment of money to the devil impossible, since debtor
learns that the devil is dead.

When the debt is due he offers the creditor his loyalty. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No.
568.
Hogs used as a mortgage collateral.
False offer to return goods in place of payment.
Milk bought on credit poured into one container.

The trickster buys it from various women. After it is all
poured together he says that each may have her own back. *Pauli (ed Bolte) No.
644.
Order to put a small vessel of milk into huge container.

Shrewd group each by himself pours water thinking this
will not be detected if the others pour milk. India: Thompson-Balys.
Trickster gets strong drink by trickery in returning goods.

Trickster returns a bottle of water instead of the bottle
of rum he has just purchased.

Trickster fills his gallon jug half full of water, then has
it filled with rum at the store.

When
seller refuses credit, he pours back half gallon of the liquid--now half rum
and half water. Sometimes trickster repeats operation, getting richer mixture
with each transaction. U.S.: *Baughman.

Debtor tells creditor that he has had his reward in the
hope of payment.
Toad receives water from frog; refuses earth in return.
Servant refused payment because of single mistake.
Man refuses to pay murderer for killing and kills him.
Fish promised in return for bacon.

Later: “Drink up the river, you shall then have fish. All
the fishes there are mine.” Lithuanian: Balys Index No. *1634; Russian:
Andrejev No. *2104.

The
devil keeps calling daily until the gate with the inscription rots. He then
claims his debtor. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1183*; Russian: Andrejev No.
1183*.
Agreement to leave sum of money on coffin of friend.

One puts on his share in cash; other makes out a check for
the total amount and takes cash left by the other. U.S.: *Baughman.
To pay beggar for standing in tank all night.

Beggar sees lights in temple. Payment refused since beggar
has thus warmed himself. India: Thompson-Balys.

Palm rat, when asked to throw down nuts according to
bargain, replies that he is deaf when eating. Africa: Weeks Jungle 400.

content:
Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 68, 375, (Hottentot): Bleek 50 No.
