24, (Benga): Nassau 198 No. 29; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 349 No.
61.
child:
By using verse with double meaning man appropriates
borrowed goods.

One day and one night: object borrowed for a day and a
night retained.

Fairy (god?) loses stronghold by consenting to lend it for
“a day and a night.”
Bird has new clothes made: flies away without paying.

Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 37 No. 244; India: *Thompson-Balys;
Japanese: Ikeda.
Drinkers argue about who is to pay.

Trickster sends one of each pair back to be stretched,
leaves town with pair of boots made up of the remaining boots. England:
Baughman.

Man orders a bottle of beer, then returns it and takes a
loaf of bread instead.

He refuses to pay
for the bread because he has returned the beer undrunk. He refuses to pay for
the beer because he has not drunk it. U.S.: Baughman.
Jackal refuses payment for being carried.

Healer to take payment in satisfaction at patient‘s
recovery.
Buyer refuses to pay more. India: Thompson-Balys.

Woman promises marriage for pair of earrings: she escapes
with them.
Devil loses his grain and gets thistles.

God grants the devil one grain crop, which he can create
by calling its name. The devil is tricked into forgetting the name and calling
“Thistles”. Hence his crop is of thistles. Dh I 185ff.

A man dreams of an egg hanging under his bed. An interpreter demands
half of what he finds as his fee for interpreting the dream. The man finds that
the egg is a silver cup filled with gold crowns. He gives the interpreter part
of the cup but none of the gold. The interpreter says, “He gave me some of the
egg-white but none of the yolk.” *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 616.

Pseudo-magic money-dropping ass beaten to death by buyer;
cheat says: “Return my ass, I shall return your money.”

Payment in worthless goods which are alleged to be valuable
goods transformed.

content:
King promises beggars new clothes: burns their old and gets
much gold and silver.

Keeps it. Wesselski
Theorie 15; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Customer takes invitation to buy as invitation to receive
the goods free.
Death feigned to avoid paying debts.

The trickster castrates the dupe and is to come the next
day and be castrated himself. He sends his wife as substitute. *Types 153,
1133; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn I (1892) 441, (1928) 276--81.
Creditor falsely reported insane when he demands money.

*Wesselski Arlotto II 225 No. 92; Gonnella 98 No. 2;
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1525L*; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

The debt will be returned to the devil when the pigs walk
instead of run home.

Horse bought on condition that the buyer pay ten florins and owe sixteen. In
court the buyer insists on the bargain and shows that if he pays the sixteen
florins which he owes he will break the bargain, for then he would no longer
owe. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 110; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

The
student is to come into the devil’s power if at the end of a year he does not
at least return for the heaping bushel of gold a level one. The student forthwith
hands back the level bushel and keeps the surplus. *Type 1182; *BP III 14 n. 3,
364.
Payment to be made when last leaf falls.
Payment to be made at harvest of first crop.

The man plants acorns.
*Type 1185; cf. 1184; Danish: Kristensen Danske Sagn III (1895) 382; German:
Schambach und Müller Niedersächsische Sagen und Märchen No. 170.

In talking the trickster makes gestures and scratches without
detection. *Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XIX 310 n. 2; North Carolina: Brown Collection I
701; India: Thompson-Balys; American Negro (Georgia): Harris Nights 214 No. 37,
(South Carolina): Parsons JAFL XXXVIII 218; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 36 No.
29; West Indies: Flowers 502.

The priest made sick of his bargain: three words at the
grave.

A poor man in return for a steer
gets permission from the priest to speak three words at the burial of his
enemy, the rich man. Priest: “From earth are you come.” Man: “Now the steer is
dead.” Priest: “In earth shall you remain.” Man: “Father, do you want the
meat?” Priest: “I wish you were in hell!” etc. Danish: Kristensen Vore Fædres Kirketjeneste 139ff.; 152ff.
child: Devil is made sick of his bargain.

Devil helps shepherd boy become a minister on condition
that he mention Satan by name each time he enters pulpit. Boy consents but does
so in such a way that devil begs to abolish the agreement. Finnish-Swedish:
Wessman 11 No. 87.

content: The price of a lump of gold.

A trickster asks a goldsmith what he would pay for a lump
of gold of a certain size. Believing that the man has such a lump, the
goldsmith pays him a large sum. Type 1541****.
child:
Man asks peddler what he pays for mink skins. Peddler says he will pay ten
dollars. The man tosses a skin into the cart, receives ten dollars. The next day
the peddler protests that the man has sold him a cat skin. The man says that he
had not said that the skin was a mink skin and that, anyway, the cat‘s name had
been “Mink.” U.S.: Baughman.

content:
New bags for old! Recovery of the old bag (containing money
or having magic power) which the stupid wife has given away.

The husband exchanges a new bag for it. *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin II 201 No. 393; Chauvin V 64 n. 1.
The fee used up before the main question is reached.

A man with an unsolved question seeks the help of a wit.
The latter refuses to answer unless paid. He takes small fees for each easy
question leading up to the principal question. Before reaching that point the
fee is exhausted, and the question remains unanswered. Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 214 No. 39.

child: Deceptive wager: whose horse will jump highest.
Deceptive wager: cat to carry lantern into room.

content:
Trickster feigns ability to influence the sun; sells
services.

Sun to shine on fools‘ backs as
they go to town in morning and return in afternoon. India: Thompson-Balys.

Trickster persuades girl to reveal hidden gold by promising
to make it into ornaments.
Trickster sells what is not his to sell.
child:
Man contracts for load of hay on the road (without making
any payment), orders the seller to deliver it at a certain inn.

He then goes to the inn, sells the hay to the innkeeper,
and pockets the money. The owner of the hay delivers it at the inn, tries to
collect at the inn; the trickster absconds. England: Baughman.

content:
Dupe kills his wife (mother) and is unable to resuscitate
her. *Type 1535, 1539; BP II 10; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s
list No. 275.
child:
Seven devils’ wives imitate ritual of death and
resuscitation done over hero;

not having
the real water of life and death, the seven enemy devils are killed. India:
Thompson-Balys.

It already has the ingredients in it. Jamaica: Beckwith
MAFLS XVII 242 No. 16.

content:
Types 1535, 1539; *BP II
10; Köhler-Bolte I 323; Missouri French: Carrière.

child:
Alleged to be a swift
deliverer of letters. *Type 1539; *BP II 10; Köhler-Bolte I 323; *Herbert III
35; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Alleged speaking hare sold as messenger.

Two jars full of live black wasps sold as interpreters of
foreign language.

Parrot knowing only two words sold as speaking foreign
language.

content: Sale of dead buffalo by making him seem alive.

child:
Said to swallow up the cold so that if he is near, one may
sleep comfortably in the cold. India: *Thompson-Balys.
Dog alleged to chase hare and bring it to hunter’s home.
Sale of dog supposed to excrete sweet dung: dupe deceived.
Horse which will not go over trees.

Salesman tells buyer that he is selling the horse because
it eats too much and will not climb trees. On the way home the horse bites
everyone and refuses to cross a bridge. Seller is literally correct. *Wesselski
Bebel I 133 No. 33; *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 112; England: Baughman; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. *1631.
The horse swifter than the rain.

Caught in the rain, a trickster finds that his horse will
not budge. He undresses, puts his clothes under the horse’s belly and keeps
them dry. When he reaches the king, he reports that his horse has run so fast
that he has had no time to get wet. The king buys the horse. *Wesselski Hodscha
Nasreddin I 228 No. 72.

Trickster grooms master‘s old mule and then sells him back
without detection at huge profit.

Trickster in disguise regains possession of his own horse
by trading with man whom he has duped once before.

He gives a description that is literally correct. U.S.:
*Baughman.
Selling or trading a balky horse.

Trickster temporarily lames valuable horse and buys him for
trifle.
Animals made by magic exchanged for real ones.
The magic animals disappear. Welsh: MacCulloch Celtic 96.
Fishing-rod alleged to take fish to fisherman’s home.
Pseudo-magic acorns: to protect holder‘s pigs.

content: Sale of tree with alleged magic fruit.
child: Sale of tree alleged to produce clothes.
Green plantains sold as matured plants.

content: Exchange of alleged ghee (liquid butter) for goat (cow).
child: Pus from sore sold as ghee.

Earthen pot with rice water on top of which clarified
butter had been poured sold as a pot of clarified butter.

content: Sale of worthless glass as diamond.

child: Pot of cow dung covered with cheese sold as cheese.
Deceptive exchange: useless for magic object.

content: Sale of a sausage filled with blood.
Cheaters sell each other valueless articles.

child:
Trick exchange: basket of stones for one of bread; a few
pieces of money shown through slit in basket-cover to dupe.

content: Sale of gilded (plated) ware as gold or silver.

Trickster, as watchman, exchanges worthless bag for bag of
gold at night.

child:
Woman sold a letter to wear around her neck which will
prevent eye trouble. It helps only so long as she believes in it. *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 153.
Alleged healing letter (charm) sold: to aid in childbirth.

Actually works. When opened it contains nonsense. Italian
Novella: Rotunda.
Pseudo-magic letter is found to contain insulting remarks.
Pseudo-magic charm (letter): to ward off plague.

Pseudo-magic letter (charm): to aid in engendering
offspring.

A sailor boy sells a seasick Jew “Babylon stones” as a
cure. They are pieces of coal. Type 1532*.
Found to contain snake’s eggs. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

The dupe takes it. “It is dog‘s dung,” he says and spits
it out. The trickster says that he is telling the truth and demands pay.
*Wesselski Gonnella 99ff. Nos. 4, 4a, 105 No. 9; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Sale of alleged oracular bamboo cup.
Betrayal through pretended fountain of youth.

*Type 1539; BP II 10ff.; Penzer V 5--13; Italian Novella:
Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Coster-Wijsman 26 No. 5.

*Type 1539; BP II 10; *Fb “hat” IV 202b; India:
Thompson-Balys; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII 196, 443.
Pseudo-magic formula for making gold sold to king.

Gold required for its manufacture carried off by
manufacturer. Spanish Exempla: Keller.
Deceptive sale of another as slave.

content:
Monkey instead of girl in floating basket: hermit made
laughing-stock.

He has persuaded girl’s foolish father to place
her in the basket. Prince takes girl and leaves monkey in her place. (Cf.
†K1333, †K1674.) Penzer II 445.
The bribed boy sings the wrong song.

The sexton steals the priest‘s cow. The next day the
sexton’s son sings, ”My father stole the priest‘s cow.“ The priest pays the boy
to sing the song in church. But the sexton teaches the boy a new song, ”The
priest has lain with my mother,“ and this is sung in church. England, U.S.: Baughman; Danish:
Kristensen Vore Fædres Kirketjeneste 88ff.; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 144 No.
1735A*; West Indies: Flowers 541f.
Fox leads ass to lion‘s den but is himself eaten.
Cock‘s advice proves disastrous to himself.

He causes the ox and the ass to rebel but the master
learns the cause of the trouble and kills him. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 36 No.
207*.
Partnership of Honesty and Fraud: Fraud loses.

Fraud has cheated his partner, Honesty. They hire a
housekeeper. Fraud is to have use of her right side, Honesty of her left. The
left side is of little use. Fraud falls in love with her and pays Honesty
double all his losses to relinquish his rights. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 99 No.
837, Keller.

Old woman planning to kill hero in swinging game by
cutting rope is killed when hero cuts the rope first. N. A. Indian: *Thompson
Tales 324 n. 169.
Flattering foreman tricked by his master.

He always answers his master’s remarks, ”I have thought of
the same thing too.“ He falls into the trap when his master says, ”I am going
to sow salt.“ Type 1574*.
Marooned man reaches home and outwits marooner.
child:
The father-in-law has the youth hunt eggs on an island and deserts him, but the
youth outwits him. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 326 n. 175. Cf. Spanish:
Espinosa II No. 49.

Marooned man hides himself in ogre‘s clothes and outwits
him.

content:
Hero given arrows with soft points and sent after dangerous enemies. The
deception discovered and the enemy discomfited. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales
312 n. 121.

Father delivering daughter to be eaten by cannibal is himself
eaten.

The ogre plans to burn the hero’s moccasins while they are
camping together, but the hero exchanges the moccasins. N. A. Indian: *Thompson
Tales 325 n. 172.
Message of death fatal to sender.

(Gang nach dem Eisenhammer.) A man is sent by the king to
burners of a kiln who have been instructed to throw the first arrival into the
fire. The intended victim goes elsewhere and the king’s son (or the man‘s accuser), who next
arrives, is burned instead. *Type 930; **J. Schick Das Glückskind mit dem
Todesbrief (1932); *Aarne FFC XXIII 73ff.; *Penzer II 113; **Cosquin Études
73ff., 129ff.; *Chauvin VIII 145; *Fb ”teglovn“; *Wesselski Mönchslatein
40 No. 34; *Oesterley No. 283; Scala Celi 130b No. 713; *Herbert III 198, 589;
*Gaster Exempla 239f., 246f. Nos. 320, 345; *Hilka Neue Beiträge zur
Erzählungsliteratur des Mittelalters No. 6; *bin Gorion Born Judas V 226f.;
Verdam Handelingen en Mededeelingen der Maatschappij der Nederlandsche
Letterkunde (1898--99; bijlage) 1ff.; *Taylor MPh XV 177; BP IV 352; Hdwb. d.
Märchens I 509; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17 No. 8.--Icelandic:
Sveinsson FFC LXXXIII xxiv, Boberg; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys; Indonesia:
DeVries’s list No. 229, Voorhoeve No. 151, 142.
child: Person sends wrong man to sleep with king‘s daughter.

In revenge villain orders whoever first enters temple to
be killed. Villain accidentally enters and is slain. Irish myth: Cross.

content: Poisoner poisoned with his own poison.
child: Would-be poisoner forced to drink poisoned cup.

Person trying to blow poison on another is himself
poisoned.

Chauvin II 87 No. 22; Zs. d. dt. Morgenl. Ges. XLII 115ff.; B[ö]dker Exempler
280 No. 23; Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Wife poisons husband who in turn poisons her.

Before he dies he forces her to drink from the same cup.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Person gives his wife a poisoned drink; she pours the two
drinks together.

Poisoner’s own son takes the beverage intended for
step-brother.

Son who intends to poison father drinks the poison by
mistake.
Snake killed by incantation he has taught clever woman.

content: Substituted caps cause ogre to kill his own children.

The hero and heroine change places in bed with the ogre‘s
children and put on them their caps so that the ogre is deceived. *Types 327,
1119; *BP I 124 n. 1; French Canadian: Barbeau JAFL XXIX 22; India:
*Thompson-Balys; N. A. Indian: Thompson CColl II 358ff.; (Northern Paiute
[Paviotso]): Lowie JAFL XXXVII 226 No. 10; Cape Verde Islands: *Parsons MAFLS
XV (1) 73 n. 3; Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 267 No. 77.
child: Substituted string causes ogre to be killed.

Intended victim of cannibal is marked by thread around
ankle. Changed in night to host. India: Thompson-Balys.

Guest to be killed suspects plot and forces host to sleep
in his bed.

Brothers come home and kill
their father. Irish myth: *Cross.

Girl takes place of impostor in marriage bed; impostor‘s
mother beats her, thinking she is heroine.
Noose changed so that ogre’s daughter is dragged to death.

Kid puts one of tigress‘s cubs in his place: she eats the
cub.

content:
Trickster makes believe he has found a purse (which he had
filled with lead).

Merchant claims it and
pays ten crowns for it. Trickster wins ensuing suit. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Trickster sells dog for mutton or for opossum. He later
eats the dog which has been given to a friend of his by the purchaser. U.S.:
*Baughman.
Teacher instructs pupil in the art of love: cuckolded.

Student, ignoring woman‘s identity, seduces the teacher’s
wife, and reports success to him. The teacher makes futile attempts to surprise
wife with pupil. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Tries to avoid paying tax by hiding eggs in his breeches.
The collectors make him sit down. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
The woman as cuckoo on the tree shot down.

The anger bargain is to cease when the cuckoo crows. The
ogre‘s wife
climbs the tree and imitates the cuckoo. She is shot down. *Type 1029;
Köhler-Bolte I 151; Wünsche 29, 33, 36ff., 47, 51ff., 61, 106; Fb ”tjære“ III 811a; Irish myth:
Cross; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa III Nos. 163--7; Cape Verde
Islands: Parsons MAFLS XV (1) 115.
child: A man in place of a cuckoo.

A cruel master commands his serf to climb a tree and
imitate the cry of the cuckoo; he shoots the ”cuckoo.“ Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 3745.

Disliking early rising, the servant kills devil’s mother or grandmother, who
crows in place of the cock. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 1029A*.

content:
Woman who tries to push husband into river falls in when he
steps aside.

She drowns because she has
tied his hands and he is unable to aid her. (She also thinks he is blind
because she has fed him rich food to induce blindness.) (Cf. Type 1380.) U.S.:
*Baughman.

Swindlers allowed to hide money: proves to be basket of
stones.
Pretended sick man aroused by beating.
child:
Woman, who pretends to faint, comes to life when beaten by
magician in order to drive out alleged evil spirit.

content: Woman bitten by own fierce watchdog.

The trickster meets a man in a narrow place in the road and calls out to him to
make room. The man refuses and the trickster turns over the cart. In court the
trickster plays dumb. The plaintiff says, ”He is not dumb; he called out to me
several times to get out of the way.“ Damages are assessed against the
plaintiff for negligence. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin II 210 No. 425.

Unjust official outwitted by peasant who quarrels with him
and thus turns the attention of the ruler to the abuses.

*Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 847; Nouvelles de Sens. No. 1;
Lithuanian: Balys Historical.

Dwarf himself falls in love with girl he has seduced by
magic love, and loses her as he is forced to remove his magic.

Sage’s advice followed: he is killed so that sacrifice can
be mixed with his blood.
Lawyer agrees to pay debt on winning his first case.

He refuses to plead so as not to pay. Debtor sues him for
double the amount due him. If he wins he has to pay and if he loses he has to
pay double. He settles debt. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Bear (tiger) substituted for woman in floating box;

kills villain who tries
to steal the woman. (Cf. †K1625.) India: *Thompson-Balys.

child: Earl killed in combat with man he has undertaken to kill.

Treacherous counselor killed in treacherous ballgame he
himself has arranged.

Boiling water meant for cooking hero used for man who has
prepared it.
S. Am. Indian (Amuesha): Métraux RMLP XXXIII 150.

content:
Woman ordered to strip has lover turn his back; pushes him
into water (pit).

(Cf. †K551.4.3, †K926, †K1210.) U.S.: Baughman. Cf. Child Ballad
No. 4.
Thief climbing rope discovered and rope cut.

He has tricked the guardian of the food-supply in the tree
(by imitation of the owner’s voice or the discovered pass-word) to let down the
rope. *Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 242 No. 17.
Tiger in sheep‘s clothing stolen by sheep-thief.

Comparetti PFLS IX 144; *Jamaica: Beckwith MAFLS XVII 236
No. 5.
Magician challenged to make good his false claim.

Says he can take black and white dogs and make them gray
and then reverse process. Trickster furnishes gray dog and challenges magician
to show his power. India: Thompson-Balys.
Ambushed trickster killed by intended victim.

*Penzer V 59 n. 2; Irish myth: Cross; India:
Thompson-Balys; Africa (Ekoi): Talbot 69; Jamaica: *Beckwith MAFLS XVII 247 No.
23.
child:
Husband intending to push wife down mountain is pushed over
by her.

content:
They have killed the cock for waking them too early, but
their mistress punishes them. Wienert FFC LVI 64 (ET 279), 116 (ST 262); Halm
Aesop No. 10.
Animal strangled by victim which he tries to eat.

B[ö]dker Exempler 281
No. 26; Chauvin II 88 No. 24.

Woman who engages false bridegroom for her daughter has
plans go astray.
Deceiver falls into his own trap (literally).

Arranges a trap or pitfall but is himself caught. Type
1117; Africa: Werner African 214, (Hottentot): Bleek 78; Jamaica: Beckwith
MAFLS XVII 254 No. 33; West Indies: Flowers 539.
child: Pitfall arranged but victim escapes it.

content: Man falls into sacrificial grave prepared for others.

Rich man orders poor people to dig a grave in order to
bury all in it as sacrifice to avert famine. But a Christian frees them and
promises those who become Christian a living. The rich man himself falls in the
grave and dies. Icelandic: Boberg.

Sons have servant impersonate dead father and falsify his
will.

Servant deceives them by favoring
himself. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Thief-catcher caught by his own magic club.

After the culture hero has instituted death, his own child
dies and he repents in vain. N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 285 n. 52,
(California): Gayton and Newman 59, 64; Africa: Werner African 162.
child: Inventor of death machine is first to use it.
Spanish Exempla: Keller; Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Tables turned on procuress by chaste wife.

The old woman is enticed into the wife’s room, beaten, and
driven forth naked. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 408.
Disguised trickster beaten by man he is trying to frighten.

Disguise as ghost. Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 47 No. 326,
Espinosa II Nos. 136--138.
child:
Man decides to frighten another (or his son or servant).
He dresses in a sheet; his pet monkey puts on a sheet and follows him. The
person who is doing the scaring hears the victim say, ”Run Big Fraid, run;
Little Fraid‘ll get you.“ The scarer sees the monkey in the sheet, runs home. (Cf. †K1833.)
Canada, England, U.S., Wales: *Baughman.

content: The treasure-finders who murder one another.

Two (three) men find a treasure. One of them secretly puts
poison in the other‘s wine, but the other kills him, drinks the wine and dies.
*Type 763; Chaucer’s ”Pardoner‘s Tale“; *F. N. Robinson Complete Works of
Geoffrey Chaucer (Boston, 1933) 834; *BP II 154; *Basset 1001 Contes III
181ff.; *Chauvin VIII 100 No. 73; *Wesselski Morlini 293 No. 42; *Bolte
Montanus 564; *Basset RTP XIV 440; *Hart MPh IX 17; *Wells MPh XXV
163.--Italian Novella: Rotunda; Jewish: *bin Gorion Born Judas IV 41, 276;
India: Cowell J[a]taka I 124, *Thompson-Balys; Chinese: Chavannes 500 Contes I
386 No. 115; Eberhard FFC CXX 201f.; Korean: Zong in-Sob 186 No. 81.

Seller of pardons robbed by man whom he has pardoned
beforehand.

The defence declared good by
the judge. *Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 301; Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 63; Italian
Novella: *Rotunda.

Men
exchange jobs because each is made to believe that the other‘s is easier. It is
not. India: Thompson-Balys.
Tail sticking from ground betrays killing of calf.

So arranged by servant in revenge on his master. India:
Thompson-Balys.

Unjust banker deceived into delivering deposits by making
him expect even larger.

In order to make the impression of honesty he delivers the one
chest of money. The ten chests which he then receives are filled with stones.
Penzer III 118ff.; Hdwb. d. Märchens I 96a; *Chauvin IX 24 No. 13; Boccaccio
Decameron VIII No. 10 (Lee 266); *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 27; Spanish:
Boggs FFC XC 135 No. 1617*, Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish: *Neuman,
*bin Gorion Born Judas II 131, 346, IV 132, 281; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child:
Blind man gets back his stolen treasure by making thief
expect a larger one.

Buried money is stolen. Blind owner pretends that he is
going to bury more. Thief returns the money hoping to get all. Blind man
recovers original treasure. Spanish: Childers; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
Blind man asks thief to invest a larger sum for him.

The greedy thief puts back the stolen money hoping to get
more. The blind man recovers his money. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

content:
(Pathelin.) On the advice of a lawyer, the
client feigns insanity when arraigned in court. When the fee is demanded, he
still feigns insanity. *Type 1585; *Prato RTP IX 537; *Dubsky RTP XXIII 427;
Köhler-Bolte I 362; **Oliver JAFL XXII 395; *Bolte Wickram’s Rollwagenbüchlein 371 No. 36; Scala Celi 8a No. 51.--Italian
Novella: *Rotunda; India: Thompson-Balys; Africa (Gold Coast): Barker and
Sinclair 139 No. 26; West Indies: Flowers 542.
child:
Lawyer‘s client therefore refuses payment of fee. India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
A lover is let down into a girl‘s room at night in a
basket. The spying parent stumbles into the basket and is jolted about by the
lover’s confederate. The parent thinks the devil has got him and leaves the
lovers in peace. von der Hagen III 36 No. 55; English: Child No. 281.
The order for six loads of snow.

The order is given by the king in winter. The courtier
waits until summer to present the order. Gets money as substitute. Chauvin VIII
149 No. 149.
Mole as trickster killed in his own tunnel.

He tricks the fox by going through the tunnel and eating
the common food, but the fox sees the molehill and kills him. Africa (Angola):
Chatelain 203 No. 29.
